So I saw this game while looking a "Four Pack" game on Steam, I really loved the idea of this game, but its a shame I'll be refunding it just 30 minutes after buying it

This games really looks fun to play with friends, but the lack of servers is a big issue, and you can't create your own server with game mechanics, the workaround is making people (who already bought the game) pay a fee each month to a third party software so you can play with your friends...

Dev, do you know the "Risk of Rain" game? they even joked on the launch of RoR2 because of the port fowarding needed to play online on the first game, you are not only making the same mistake as they did on their first game, but you are not even thinking in changing that, and just says that the workaround is to pay for a service, and this is most likely people that will buy the service will give you some percentage since people will use your code

I really expect this game to change, to be able to create listen server rooms and invite friends on steam to join and play

until then, i'll just follow the game to receive patch notes

Its a really great idea, it looks like its well implemented, but for a game that's supposed to be played online, there is no reason for it to be hard to play online.

review:
We play 3 or 4-player games on LAN. For such low number of players, the default settings are somewhat unbalanced. The main problem is that with default settings, the optimal strategy for the robo player is to just keep killing everyone as soon as they land. If you play a 3 player game, I recommend adjusting the server settings: lowering the respawn timer to 35 or 40 and making the ship easier to crash by lowering the threshold to 2000. This makes the "killer" strategy non-viable because the player has to spend to buy new ships all the time or risk being overthrown.

I was sceptical that it's early access with no updates for almost a year now, but the game is already fun and playable from start to finish as it is. There are some bugs (like you cannot set the respawn timer lower than 31 seconds), but none of it is game breaking. It's a great game overall. I bought 4-pack for $20 and it's really worth it.

review:
This is a fantastic game, suffice it to say. It's set around the concept of getting your enemies to act against their own self interest, which you may be confused about, after all, why would your opponents try to help you win? Well, because they think that it'll also help themselves win. The victor is typically the one who best enlists the help of the other players while keeping them thinking that they're not actually sabotaging themselves. Either that or that one bunny which just plays perfectly obedient the whole game yet still somehow wins because they're getting steady progress towards that 10,000 cent goal while everyone else is squabbling to be overlord.

As I sort of alluded to in that last paragraph, the goal is to recieve 10,000 points. These points are presumably a currency of some kind, but it's not actually named, so I just call them cents, because the symbol looks similar. The way you go about gaining 10,000 cents will vary depending on playstyle, you may become overlord at the very beginning of the round, and simply never lose the position, or you'll be the aforementioned player that just does everything the overlord asks yet doesn't lose to them.

Now, presuming you're reading this while having NO idea how the game works, at the beginning of the game, every player is dropped into the world with a bunny avatar. The players all race to the large robot seen in the right hand side of the game's thumbnail. This robot is Robosaru, and it's the centerpiece of every game of Obey. Once the first player reaches Robosaru, they become overlord. The overlord's objective is the same as any other player's, but they now have the ability to use their machine gun to kill any player within their vision, and even detonate the obedience collars of players you can't see. So one may ask how Robosaru has any chance of losing, which is simple: the other bunnies are more valuable to him alive than dead, which gives them a chance to succeed. The overlord will typically force the other players to bring uranium to his collection box, which will give him a substantial amount of money, but of course, the other players won't do this for free, so the overlord can set auto-pay on his boxes to give the other players a specific amount of money every time they deposit uranium.

Essentially, it's a boss-worker relationship, except the overlord is more like a dictator.

Any player can become the NEW overlord at any time, the same way that the first player did, running up to Robosaru's door and entering it. This kicks out the first player, who is now just a lowly bunny, and suddenly you have the exact same scenario, just with a different overlord. But, of course, it's not that simple, as the overlord can kill you at any moment that he can see you. It's not even as simple as staying out of his sight, as your obedience collar lets him know exactly where you are at all times. So what do you do? Well, you take the collar off. But this is a dangerous prospect, since every player gets passive income over time. If memory serves, the overlord gets 8 cents a second, collared bunnies get 4 cents a second, and uncollared bunnies get 2 cents a second. So taking your collar off for a substantial amount of time is very risky. Even more risky is if you get killed, because then you get sent to the dropship. Not only does this mean you can't deposit uranium, and therefore collect funds, but your passive income also drops to 1 cent per second in the dropship, even if you're wearing an obedience collar.

That's pretty much how Obey works. A bit of a complicated and messy explanation, but hopefully it sufficed. Now onto the actual review.

The mechanics, as detailed above, are absolutely flawless. Just fantastic. The music is very dystopian, which helps sell the overlord as a ruthless dictator. I especially like the main menu theme. The art-style is nice, and I was a big fan of the little details, like how the bunnies breath so quickly due to the fact that they're very probably scared witless. The only real criticism I have for this game is that not enough people are playing it, which is actually why I'm writing this review, in the hopes it may attract more players to the game. BUT! Even if it's better with real other players, the bots in this game are actually remarkably good, to the point that I actually find myself losing to them sometimes. Of course, bots are no substitute for human interaction, and playing with them instead of real people does lose the human element, but I'd still say it's worth the money.

The big thing is smoother animation for the main robot, as it feels it lags too much in animation. I get using them as cover can be a good thing, but still lessening the time they stay can still make them usable. Aside from those major things, only other thing I'd recommend is more tools for the one in the giant robot to use to keep track of others and more options for others to try and sneak into the robot outside of water and bushes and using upper ground as walls. It's a good game, but needs those few patches and tweeks to make it a solid one and I want to see this one become a solid game.

review:
OBEY is one of the most interesting concepts in multiplayer i've seen in indie games in recent years. The game revolves around a assymetrical take on the king of the hill mode. The main objective is having the most money. For this, you want to conquer the tower, which gives you the absolute powers over everyone else on the map. You can command people to do your bidding and earn money for you. (they also earn their share of the money). You can destroy people who disobey or try to overthrow you. On the other hand, as a regular rabbit, you have to do your best to escape the clutches of the tower. By either playing along to lull the person in charge to a sense of security, planning distractions, sneaking. All is based around mind games and trying to trick each other, and the tower can even do stuff like bribing other players to keep an eye on you and report you if they notice you trying to sneak into the door. Communication and misdirection are all keys to success.

Do be warned that the userbase is a bit low these days, but by asking around the forum you can get some matches started, and there's also the option of buying a 4pack if you want to play with your friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994557935', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1629652380}
review:
A very unique social king of the hill game, where the current king has tools to coerce other players into serving him for a share of profit.

On the surface its a simple king of the hill game where everyone tries to climb into a massive turret and then fight everyone else off. Which is not an easy task all by itself as the overlord has a very limited vision and a limited firing arc.
However, once you take the turret over, you may choose to invest some of your score into penalising other players for dying and incentivising them players to work for you. But of course, if you lose control, the new overlord inherits all of your investments.

As the current overlord you have to choose how to best incentivise other players to obey and making you money.
As a defenseless bunny you must choose either to obey and earn a small share of income, or rebel and risk earning nothing at all.

As result, the social component is extremely important in this game, which means the dead playerbase is a massive issue.
Buy it only if you can find 5-7 friends to play with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037457084', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1564625647}
review:
[h1]The Positives[/h1]

1. It's like King of the Hill more or less, as the description stated, the longer you hold the robot, the more money you make. It's a concept alot of people are familiar with, and once you learn the controls, (ex. Increase/Decrease Autopay, Purchasing Items, ect.) it's really easy to master. The hard part is mastering how to trick everyone!

2. It's really helirious to be anything you wanna be, you can be a snitch, sitting on a tower, spotting out people to get destroyed by the overlord, you can play as the overlord with an arsenal of things to obliterate anyone you want, or you can play as a good bunny, and passively do whatever the robot tells you. It really does feel amazing to have such options in a game, most games either you are bad, or good, but this game, you can be a no-tolerance overlord, but still be a good guy and pay your bunnies fairly. But I think the funniest part about it, is the varying reactions you get from people.

3. It's easy, and appealing to the eyes. The cartoony style fits well with the setting and it honestly makes it feel cozy to be in a lobby with other people.

4. The people you'll play with are not heavily competitive. Not that I've noticed atleast, as no one really tries super duper hard, or gets super salty when you take over. It's a nice change of pace from most multiplayers out there.

5. The bunnies are just about the cutest darn thing I've ever seen in a video game. Slime Rancher's Slimes have competition with how adorable the jumping, squeaking, and hopping is. It makes you go 'Awww" every time.

6. People say the servers are ghost towns, but if you join a lobby, play and mess about with the bots for a bit, people will join in. I had it happen to me several times over. It just takes a bit of time, remember, the community is small. Insta-games won't happen until the community reachs 5000 players or so!

[h1]The Negatives[/h1]
1. For a bunny rabbit, who can sprint at a maximum of 30 to 25 miles per hour, you move more like a turtle. Very slowly. And there is no sprint option.

2. If you are hoping for a new experience everytime...It is a small community still, so you will run into the same people pretty much every time you play the game. For some, this is a good thing, familiarity is nice. But for people like me, who like to see different styles, and different things done, if you run into the same group, it feels sort of frustrating, because you know what to expect.

3. You kinda have to be social to play this game. This is under the negative, because I know it is very difficult for some to put themselves out there as it were. And I know some people who looked at this game thought it would be neat, until they read about how having a mic is pretty much imperative, all I can really say is if you really think you'll like it, even though you don't feel socially apt, give it a go! I certainly did, and I loved it.

TL;DR: Gameplay, Art Style, Concept are amazing, and The game is mostly bug free. Negatives: Small, if not tiny community, Servers don't get populated very fast, and It'll definitly put you out of your comfort zone if you don't like using your mic/hearing other people use theres.

review:
Obey is a neat game, with a unique concept - The game wont hold your hand, it may give you the fundamentals of playing but the finer points are what control the flow of the game. Bunnies can work together, with the robot, solo or in small groups to make their way to victory, with their own aims in mind. The Robot's rise to victory is less subtle than a bunnies, but he has many tools at his disposal, and a good robot can control his bunnies with them - most of the time.

The Dev of this game actively communicates on the Steam forums, responding to comments and suggestions and seems to take an active approach to maintain game balance, which is fragile in a game with so many options, and so far - he's managed it.

review: So far, I have played two games of OBEY, after doing the tutorial, of course. The first game was somewhat enjoyable. The player who dominated the robot tactically used bunnies against eachother, and managed to gather up a large stockpile of weaponry. Eventually though, he reached the point where giving him uranium and supplies would guarantee that the bunnies would lose, yet people still kept supplying him, instead of rushing him to try to gain control and have a chance of winning themselves. The second game I played was much worse. I took control of the robot early on, and the bunnies consisted of little kids who didn't even want to play the game, just build houses out of supplies. Eventually the more experienced players that joined immeditely left when they realized the bunnies weren't trying. When I attained a 80% of the points needed to win, some of them realized they should probably try to overthrow me. Instead of working together or trying to come up with a strategy, they ran like chickens with their heads cut off. Eventually, the smartest among them started trying to put corpses in the supply machine, which would cost me 1000's of points if succesful. Eventually someone else took control of the robot while I was distracted, but instead of working with the other players to secure an advantage, he just started shooting everyone. I then won due to a lack of any competition as my score ticked up. Overall, This game can be incredibly fun, but the community feels too much immature and unnappreciative of the intricacies that this game has. Not worth buying.

review:
Of the many games I've played in my life, OBEY has to be one of the most unique and interesting. It's an experience that's substantially different from any other game I've played. It is a ton of fun. 

I'll let other reviews explain the mechanics of the game. What I want to focus on is the strategy and drama that unfolds between the human players.

When you're in command, it's like being an evil dictator of a third-world country. You have to keep your workers in line through power, but also through cunning. Your citizens may ostensibly be helping you, but they'll betray you at any moment if you let your guard down.

When you're not in command, it's like being a citizen of an evil dictatorship. You want to rebel and take control, but you can't be too obvious about it or you'll be quickly punished. If you do rebel, you'll need to work covertly until the perfect moment to strike. Or you can cozy up to the dictator and actually earn a meager living in his shadow.

Things you'll do if you're crafty enough (when you're in command):
[list]
[*]Keep close track of all your workers (other players), to see if they are subtlely undermining you, or trying to escape.
[*]Set and enforce rules to keep your workers in line (not too strict or they will openly rebel, but not too lenient or they will take advantage of you.)
[*]Use your charisma to make the workers prefer you to another commander.
[*]Convince your loyal workers to betray the rebels in their midsts for a reward.
[*]Blow disloyal bunnies to smithereens, but then offer to forgive them so they might still go back to being in your workforce.
[/list]

Things you'll do if you're crafty enough, (when you're NOT in command):
[list]
[*]Pretend to be stupid and make "mistakes" to undermine the commander.
[*]Secretly damage the commander's goals while he isn't looking, or do things to cause society itself to fall into chaos.
[*]Threaten to stop working unless pay is increased.
[*]Cause a distraction so your allies can escape.
[*]Take advantage of chaos to make your own escape, and slowly lurk up to the command center to take control (or die trying.)
[*]Betray your fellow workers' secret plot for a reward.
[*]Lie about the location of rebels to distract the commander.
[*]Give up the true location of a rebel that is about to take power for themselves.
[*]Convince the commander to let you do things that put you in a better position (like build things a little too close to the commander to "help" him.)
[*]Win by actually being loyal to your commander.
[*]Organize coordinated rebellions or "jail breaks".
[/list]

All of the above involves using various aspects of the game's mechanics to your advantage, but also involves social engineering of the other players in order to succeed. It is possible to play without speaking to your fellow players, but voice chat is vital to getting the most out of OBEY.

OBEY gives you both an amazing sense of power, and also the delight of subverting that power. If you're looking for an experience that's likely different from anything you've played before, give OBEY a shot.

review: The game although rather fun lack a lot and simply not worth the time or money. Obey is a game where you as the player are a bunny trying to get to the center of the map so that you may control a giant robot. It sounds easy and simple at first, yet the robot is controlled by a player that is bound to kill you upon nearing the giant robot that has miniguns and rockets. You must then OBEY the player in dire hopes that you don't go up in flames or get blown up with rockets. Now the game and it's concept is indeed fun, yet the game is hard to learn and the in-game tutorial teaches you little about the actual game upon entering multiplayer. You will end up in a either a empty server or a server with one or two people and you will find it rather difficult to understand the game at first, yet if you do manage to understand the difficulty in learning the game then you will meet another obstacle. Sometimes you will find players in the robot that will constantly kill you whether or not your following orders, and at that point the game becomes Hide and Seek Killer Robot Edition. Sometimes you may be in the robot, and no one will follow your orders at all even though your trying to give easy orders. Those two things simply ruin the enjoyable aspect of the game and makes it into something so pointless. If you do manage to find some players that will play your game then congrats! You will have a few minutes of enertainment until the players leave via boredom/rage. The game after a while becomes pointless and quite repetitive as you work, plot, and either execute or fail your plot (rinse and repeat). Finally, the ONE MAJOR FACTOR IN THIS GAME is that you NEED a MICOPHONE! I cannont stress this enough! If you do not have a microphone then be prepared to lose over and over again as the bunnies steal your robot while you type a order (or they simply ignore you cause you do not have a microphone). I thankfully have a microphone to dish out pointless orders to rebeilous players that never listen. I would only reccomend this game if is on sale, you plan to play with friends, or you have a microphone and need something to waste money & time on. Obey gets 4/10 burning bunny corpses in my books

review:
This game is all about finding the right balance between trust and mistrust. There's a lot of pointing fingers and blaming going on which is extra funny because every player has exactly the same visual appearance and you cannot distinguish one player from another. It's also a lot about being unpredictable so that other player's don't understand which strategy you follow until it's too late.

This game is very original in concept so let be explain what it is about in more detail:

Everyone is a bunny. A white cuddly cute bunny that has no possiblity of harming anyone with his bunny body. BUT: There is a gigantic robot in the area that can be used to exert dominance over the other bunnies. So it is a good idea to head towards the robot, take control over it and start commanding around the other players. If they do not obey, you can very easily annihilate them with your robot guns. You are now a tyrant and the other bunnies will try to overthrow you by invading the robot themselves. So be vigilant and shoot any bunny that comes too close to your robot.

However, just being agressive will not suffice to be victorious. The objective of every player is to gain 10,000 dollars (or some other currency). Every player has a passive income. The player sitting in the robot has a passive income that is ten times as much as the income of the bunnies outside the robot. Every player can invest his money on items that might give them an advantage ingame. If done correctly, you can win the game, even if you are not in control of the robot.

The interesting thing is: Collaborating players have an advantage. But in the end there will always be only one winner and everyone else loses. So you cannot collaborate at all costs. At some point you have to fight on your own and try to get the lead.

Collaboration can happen between non-robot bunnies and the bunny in the robot. The robot can bribe/reward bunnies that bring him material to the feed box. The feed box is a box on the map where items can be placed. Some items give money or ammunition to the robot. When a bunny delivers an item to the feedbox, the robot may decide to reward him with money, so that it is a win-win situation for both players. But it is stil in the interest of every individual player that no other player has more money than himself.

The controls of the game are simple and sufficient to navigate the terrain and to control the robot. No complaints there.

This game is also fully playable at this moment, even though it is still early access. It is well balanced and it's fun to use the game mechanics to screw over other players. For example, if a bunny dies in a fire, the corpse can be collected and placed in the feed box. When this happens, the player in the robots loses 1000 dollars which is a lot of money. But getting the corpse to the feed box might be a real challenge because the player in the robot will try to monitor all traffic in the map and if he spots you carrying a corpse you have to run for your life.

I think the tutorial does a decent job at explaining the game mechanics.

The only downside of this game is that you need other players to have the best experience. The game has bots that you can play against but this is a game about betrayal and bots are obviously pretty bad at this. But they are still helpful to fill up a lobby. Remember: Every player looks the same. So you cannot even tell if you are looking at a bot or at a real player. And even though the bots are stupid, they do a pretty good job at being hard to distinguish from human players.

You can "follow" this game on Steam to receive notifications when there is a tournament. This way you will know when there are enough players online to have an interesting game.

[b]Review Written on Monday, May 2nd, 2016[/b] 

 [h1]Review[/h1] 

 OBEY é um jogo de estratégia em tempo real com interacção social entre jogadores, num mapa em 3D, onde para vencer temos de convencer os outros a fazer tarefas que muitas vezes contrariam os seus próprios objectivos, em troca de alguma outra vantagem, ganhando no final do tempo de jogo o jogador que tiver mais dinheiro acumulado. 

 O tutorial podia ser mais completo, dar um exemplo de uma estratégia para vencer e não limitar-se a descrever os comandos e a utilidade de cada objecto. Contudo, é de saudar a vontade do criador (developer) em ajudar quem quer aprender a jogar, convidando pessoalmente os interessados no steam, pelo menos nesta fase de desenvolvimento do jogo, com o objectivo de melhorar o tutorial.

 Apesar de não ser adepto de jogos exclusivamente multiplayer, reconheço que este jogo tem potencial. Realçe para o facto do jogo estar ainda inacabado.

review:
OBEY is a game that runs absolutely terrible on my turd of a PC. Nor does it run on my 2010 Macbook (Non-Pro) with only 2 GB of RAM.

With that being said, here is my semi in depth review.

Obey is a First Person multiplayer game that sets itself apart from most by focusing on team based play. It can be played online, or with bots, though the bots tend to be pretty easy. It can seem very chaotic and difficult to understand at first, although once one masters the gameplay it gets less confusing. The game's tutorial tries to teach you how to play a little, showing you what different items do and how the game works. Gameplay is basically like a very complicated King Of The Hill, in which players feed items into a massive robot controlled by one player in order to try to earn money so then the player controlling the robot can give back more items and money to the players. In terms that a sane person will understand, to win you basically need to make the most money.

Overall, the game is worth buying for people that are looking for an interesting multiplayer experience that strives to be different from your average online game.

VisGaming Score  A Sloth/10

(Honestly, this game would be really good, but its so slow on both my PC and my Mac, that I probably will wind up going back and playing again once I upgrade to something half decent.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198085792343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1448660245}
review:
Nothing I've ever played can compare to this game. There's only one word I can use to describe it: chaos.

You've only got one goal: get the most money possible.

It's crazy confusing at first. The tutorial helps, but goes so fast and is still not entirely clear (the easiest ways to play are either in the lobby with bots or by looking it up on youtube). You're thrown into a field full of junk, corpses, rocket fuels, etc. You can put these items in a "feed box" going to the robot, offering them different perks and giving you a small amount of money. However, the more loyal you are, the richer the robot gets. As a bunny, there's not much you can do besides feed the robot and hope he gives you money for being loyal.

Now, you can always go overthrow him and take control.

This opens up a whole new world of excitement. You have to constantly watch for disobeying bunnies attempting to steal your throne, pay loyal bunnies, order dropships with supplies for your bunnies to feed you, shoot disobeying bunnies, and much much more. 

Overall, it's a great game once you get the hang of it. The bots are super easy to play against, so once you know what you're doing I recommend getting with actual people to play. Mics are also extremely helpful for communication.

review:
Obey is a really fun game, in the start. No doubt. But there still is some issues. And these issues, doesn't have anything to do, with it is early access.

1. The game is really fun, with a unique concept. The problem is... It gets boring, within 1 - 2 days. The game is limited. All you do in the game is: Obey the overlord, or disobey him. Become the overlord, or stay as a bunny.

2. The game is in a lack of players. There are only 4 - 6 servers, in the game. 5 of them, are North American servers. 1 of them is a european server. There are never any europeans, playing. And when someone is playing in a north american server, there aren't that many players. There are probably only 10 players, in total, globally in this game.

So the game needs to be more populated, to actually be fun.

I do not recommend, buying this game (yet). The game developers are really great people. But i had to refund the game again, because i knew i would never play the game again. So, what this game needs is:

- Nearly unlimited interactions and items.
- More players. It's not fun to play with bots (they dont know wth they are doing).

author: {'steamid': '76561198087090645', 'num_games_owned': 4782, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1448229234}
review:
Este es un juego un tanto difícil de explicar pero voy a tratar.
El objetivo principal del juego es crear interacciones interesantes entre jugadores, poniendo mucho énfasis en la comunicación verbal (altamente recomendado jugar con un micrófono y con gente que hable tu mismo idioma).
Por esto para ganar una partida lo único que tienes que hacer es ser el primer jugador en alcanzar una cierta cantidad de dinero determinada, el como lo hagas depende completamente de tu estrategia. Al empezar todos los jugadores manejan a un conejito con una movilidad un tanto limitada, el primero en antrar en el "robot" (una torreta/torre de control) se combierte en una especie de dictador de la partida. Pero este puede ser derrocado con relativa facilidad.
Es tu desición si quieres obedecer y recibir los incentivos del líder de turno o si te combiertes tú en el líder, ambos son caminos validos para ganar.
El problema es que la diversión que puedes tener en este juego está demasiado ligada a con quien estás jugando, puede ser una experiencia memorable o lo más aburrido que puedas imaginar.
Si bien no hay mucho o casi nada que arreglar en el aspecto técnico este juego necesita un poco de pulido y refinamiento de las mécanicas de juego y el como se desarrolla una partida. Por lo que existe la posibilidad de que el resultado final sea sustancialmente diferente a lo que hay ahora, de hecho espero que el producto final sea mejor porque se nota el potencial de la idea base aquí presentada.
En resumen: como con todo juego en acceso anticipado, ten presente que este es un trabajo aún en proceso, no una pieza terminada.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034237673', 'num_games_owned': 2568, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1448316782}
review:
Have you ever played Mafia? You know, the game where you and your friends pretend you are all civilians, but some of you are actually Mafia gangsters ready to lie and take everyone out. 
Well this game has a lot of that trust & betrayal feeling to it, though instead of pretending to be some high calibre Mafiosi, you get into the flesh of small and cute little hamsters. 

You and your furry little fellows must all obey one huge monkey looking robot that watches over it all. Do as he says, and he will most probably reward you and distinguish you among your pairs. Disobey him, and you'll probably just fall under his machine-gun. 
Now, before you star assuming this developer has some sort of child induced fear to primates, let me tell you the twist of it all. The giant bad ass looking robot you see from anywhere on the map? That's actually a hamster. That's right, there's one of you just hanging in inside. That bastard got up there first to watch over you and your mates. To be the leader. One ham to rule them all.
Of course, he can't be up there all by his own. All those fancy tech you see? It won't just work of air, he needs some souls to move the gears for him, and he has just the tools to make you WANT to do it.

Now, only if you ever touched a history book in you life, can you be ignorant enough of what is fond to happen in a situation like this. Yeah, those hams won't take it for long.

The fun of it all resides in that there's no actual clear way to play this game. 
Be a loyal feud to your master and gain his trust.
Be a revolutionary leader and lead your pack to subversion.
Be a loner ham or the lunatic that makes everyone's life miserable.

No matter what you choose, you'll see where the fun is.

Words are plenty, and meaning hides in between. Welcome to social multiplayer.

review: Obeying or disobeying an order; to be killed or to help. That is what OBEY is truly all about. OBEY is a completely new genre.  The asymmetry combined with the player-driven gameplay make for one of the best multiplayer experiences that I have ever had on PC.  It is a competitive multiplayer action game where you play as adorable fluffy bunnies that will do everything in their power to coerce others to join their side of the battle. OBEY is so addicting that it is the type of game that I cannot put down.  Winning a game is one of the greatest experiences, and knowing that you did it all through dishonesty and deception makes it all the better. OBEY is not just a game I would recommend, but what you'll find is one of the most innovative experiences on PC and you will become a part of the most friendly and entertaining multiplayer community out there.

review:
OBEY is quite unique, which is pretty rare these days. The game is a king of the hill style game, you want your bunny to take control of the giant robot of doom. I highly recommend you have a mic. It makes the game considerably more fun.
The game doesn't have a huge population, so I recommend finding some friends to play with.
The dev is pretty active and helpful. He's on hand to answer questions, and even takes his time to help new players learn the game.

OBEY is very solid. It plays well, even at this early stage and is something that's a little different from every other game out there.

review:
The only appropriate tag is "multiplayer" for this game... But it is  more... You need to talk, convince, force, persuade, bribe and etc... A headset with mic is a must imho. (Although you can write/read but it is not efficient)

So although it does not seem like one, this game is about politics and ego management.

Although it is in its early stages I did not encounter any bugs.

I can write tens of pages regarding the philosophy of this game but instead I strongly advise you to buy/play it.

Perhaps a "demo time" will be nice so that people can really test it before they can be sure. As for most of the unique games, the only way to understand the game/concept is by playing it...

10/10

review:
OBEY is an interesting take on the asymmetrical multiplayer game.  The overlord is the man behind the giant gorilla turret and can see almost your every move.  The other players are bunnies who can assist the overlord or stage a coup and try and become the gunner themselves. 

Currently, the game is quite fun and look forward to the additional content that is planned for OBEY.  The art style is fitting, the controls worked as expected, and the in-game chat had no issues.

The few improvements I would like to see are a better HUD for the overlord since there are so many abilities at your disposal and a slightly more in depth tutorial (the first game I played I really didn't understand the flow of the game).

TL:DR  - Fun asymmetrical multiplayer only game with a great premise and a little light on content.  Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023455525', 'num_games_owned': 7822, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1479928610}
review:
Obey, Obey, Obey. Yea I don't think so!

First off, this game is SUPER unique, I've honestly never played any game like this before.
When I first started playing this game, I went straight for the tutorial and right after to the multiplayer part.
I quickly met this super friendly guy in-game, who was eager to show and teach me how exactly this game worked and some of the aspects in the game, which the tutorial simply couldn't show you.
It turns out, this great guy was the developer of the game, he's a really friendly and nice guy.

In this game you're a cute little bunny, your mission is to first achieve a certain amount of money.
There are different ways to do this, however, you can either be an obedient bunny and do as the robot tells you or be the disobedient bunny and take control over the robot, and start controlling the obedient bunnies.
When playing as the robot, make sure to keep track of your obedient/disobedient bunnies and make deals with them. This way they'll keep OBEYing you and you'll stay in control.

Pros:
+ Super great potential.
+ Extremely friendly community.
+ Great strategy game.
+ Negotiating with people. (Deny, deny, deny. If that doesn't work then just lie, lie, lie).
+ Choice between being the evil robot or the obedient/disobedient bunny.
+ Great response time from developer.
+ Nice variation in maps. (Game includes level editor)

Cons:
- If you don't have a mic, this game could become a little challenging.
- Not super many players yet. (This is where you come into the picture, JUST BUY IT!).


A tip I would like to give you all, "when" you buy this game is: Start out with the tutorial and try listening closely to what it tells you. When you have done that, go for an hour or two in multiplayer to get a grasp of the game and then turn back to the tutorial. I myself felt like I didn't completely understand the game after the first tutorial attempt, a bit much information to grasp for me atleast, but when I played a bit of multiplayer and got a hang of how stuff worked, I took a quick turn back to the tutorial and it just suddenly made a whole bunch of sense. 

I rate this game atleast 9/10, close to 10/10.

Would I buy this game?
Hell yea!

Would I recommend you to buy the game?
Yes, I'd even recommend you to buy a 4-pack to share with your friends!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970366868', 'num_games_owned': 4042, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1466454127}
review:
OBEY sets out to be a truly unique game and achieves that goal. Each player is dumped into the map as a harmless bunny/sheep creature whose only abilities are to pickup or drop items and perform an astonishing 1cm high jump + "squeek" combo of cuteness. There is a huge opportunity for personalising characters with accessories here, which is one of the many updates currently planned. 

The gameplay is essentially defined by the actions of the players in the match in question, but I guess you could describe the overarching type as a strategic game of power accumulation. The winner is decided by who reaches $10,000 first. The way in which they achieve that is up to them and the other players. 

A match usually begins with a mad dash to the giant robot/tower, whose occupant has a variety of extra actions available to them. If they play their cards right, they can make the other players collect resources for them which converts to money for [b][i]both[/i][/b] players. If they fail to carefully watch their subordinates, they can find sneaky ways to detract power and money or even overthrow their control of the robot. 

This is where the unique gameplay mechanics come into play. As controller of the robot, the game provides some generic warnings and instructions to place on the map for your subordinates, but the real gameplay takes place through chatting with the other players, demanding one thing or offering payment for colecting resources or making demands on threat of violence (gun turret, flamethrower, rockets).

As an online-only game (there are A.I bots that work properly, but for me the fun was completely lost without human players), the availability of friends/strangers to play with will make or break your experience with OBEY. I would highly recommend purchasing a 4-pack with some friends or finding a group to play with.

The presentation is simple but looks nice and everything seems to be very well optimised. Even though the game is in early access, I didn't encounuter any sort of bugs or glitches.

Para isso tem os itens do mapa e um robô gigante que é controlado por um jogador. Você pode obedecer os comandos do robô ou tentar tomá-lo de assalto, que é a forma mais rápidade se c onseguir dinheiro, mas não fácil. Deve se usar de stealth pra fugir das investidas do robô.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013178966', 'num_games_owned': 2509, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1478655936}
review:
[u]Game is still being developed and marked as Early Access, so minor flaws and partly absence of some content is inevitable.[/u]

[i]"Obey... And you still get scorched to ashes, annihilated with miniguns or shattered into pieces by rocket explosion. A serious game about decision making, following or being following, betrayals and loyalty with a hint of sneakiness. Aside that you take role of a cute [strike]guinea pig[/strike] bunny with some insatiable lust for money and ravage.[/i]

Now, skipping the lyrical part, game is quite good generally. Game concept where you are supposed to behave in a cat-and-mouse way, with application of being more of an armed watcher tower ["cat"], who supervises his minions and guiding them to earn more benefits, while punishing those who dare to act suspicious with death penalty, - is quite rare to meet in the industry. If I am to describe this game in short, your winning condition is to gain 10 000$ prior to any other player by any means possible, which is either obeying the tower - "boss" and working hard to bring goods in a box to gain money both for the tower and yourself, or devote yourself to rebellion and try to overtake control over the tower, and become the "boss" yourself. Tower, in fact, must observe other bunnies and try not to miss any sneaky rambos [described in a previous sentence]. Not to say, you can't figure who is who unless you want to learn people's personal behaviour and mark them in-mind.

There aren't any critical issues and I didn't happen to meet anything what could distort my experience even slightly. For the mechanics, rabbits are moving really slow while map is rather big, but such does the tower, which only has a tiny illuminated area to see over the map.  Music is neat, controls are intuitive too. There could be some better explanation guide, aside from the starting tutorial, but it's easy enough to figure on your own during your first playthough (harder with bots though, ouch).

So far game is dedicated to reach its full potential only in online mode, and sadly said, it's almost dead by the time. Good part is that there are bots to replace real players, but this way the "drama part" of interaction and cooperation within a small group of bunnies goes to the second plan, leaving in most times meaningless world for you to toy with. So, I'd strongly advise you to found a party, or seek for random people on forums, to truly enjoy the game. Also, people say that devs are often present in-game, helping beginners and leading them through sometimes puzzling aspects of the game, which is a nice touch and really good attitude towards community. I am pretty sure too that there are more updates to come, with new modes, items, mechanics and improved AI (and bigger base of players), so that may be the point where you decide to give this game a try.

Well, this ends my review. I may have been subjective at points and didn't cover some of the in-game details, but still want to describe what I felt and found enjoyable while playing [i]OBEY - small, mostly online based match game where you either seek for the power, stand for equality or go with the flow, else doing all of this at once. 

----- [b]7 one-millimeter-high bunny jumps out of 10.[/b][/i] ------

review:
A fun asymmetric multiplayer game with an adorable art style and a great game concept based around voice chatting and treachery. The player base is fairly small, but if you can get a few friends together, you're in for a great time.

The goal of the game is to get the most money by being an adorable little bunny and obeying your robot overlord! [spoiler] (Who may or may not be controlled by a bunny.) [/spoiler]
You get money at the discretion of the current robot overlord. They may place down money in reward for you taking ammunition to them or for telling them that someone is trying to overthrow them! Speaking of overthrowing, if you decide that you've had enough of following orders and want to be in charge, just head to the base of the robot and hop inside! If you can avoid the robot shooting at you, traps around the tower, and other people ratting you out!

There are several more features I haven't touched on here that can benefit and hinder you, but the real fun is convincing your opponents that you're trying to help them.

This game is absolutely worth playing if you can find some friends to play with or if you just want to try something new!

review:
In Obey, you are either the overlord in the robot tower watching over your flock of bunnies and trying to get them to your commands either by rewarding them or punishing them, or you are one of the bunnies (dis)obeying the orders of your overlord and trying to take is place.

The game requires cunning and deception as you're plotting your way to become the richest bunny in the land. While you can set up a local server and play alone against bots, due to the nature of the game you won't get the "real" experience until you play it with actual human beings far more capable of treachery than any AI can provide. Also, while not a hard requirement, a microphone is highly recommended to be able to communicate effectively with others.

Being a socially shy person, I find it a lot more fun to play with friends rather than strangers over the net. Due to the game being in early access, the community isn't that big yet and it can be difficult to find partners online outside of planned events so having friends to play with is a definitive plus.

The game still being in development, there are a few issues that I need to mention:
[list]
[*]I have had issues connecting to the online servers, it can be hit-and-miss at times.
[*]The current tutorial is a bit lacking and need to be improved upon to provide a better sense of the game to new players. 
[*]The only way to practice with bots, before you feel like you've mastered the basics and want to try playing with others, is to start a local server. I would like a "Practice" menu option that would drop me in a local game with bots.
[*]While having the possibility to run a dedicated server is a definitive plus, I would like to be able to simply host a game from the UI instead of having to manually start/stop an external server.
[/list]

That being said, the developer seems to be active in the community and has been quick to respond to suggestions and bug reports. It's a one-man labor of love.

If you like an original multiplayer game with a strong social element, you should definitively give this one a try.

review:
Obey is a very unique concept, unlike anything I've seen on (or off) Steam before.

You are in charge of a giant robot, dictator of bunnies across the land...

OR

You are a bunny, with dreams of becoming the giant robot which you Obey.

This is not a single player experience. Visuals are basic but colourful and fitting for the game. The controls are easy to pick up.

Tutorial level gives a lot of information without any other players, and it can therefore be difficult to imagine a game in practice. The inclusion of some AI for tutorial purposes may have been helpful. The tutorial did cover most of the detail of the game though.

Gameplay is fun, however at the EA stage it is difficult to find other players on mostly empty servers.

The community seems friendly, as to the developers. With any luck this game will spend a long time in Early Access to allow the fine points of the game to be polished to perfection. 

I played Crypt of the Necrodancer through the early access stage and the input from the community and openness from the developers was vital in creating what became an incredibly fun and unique experience - one which I have since happily put hundreds of hours into. I hope Obey continues in a similar vain.

---I received this game from the developer in order to review it. You will get my honest feelings about the game (both good and bad).---        

     This game is simple to play but impossible to master. You will never have the same game twice and at this point in Early Access, multiplayer is a must. With that said, I would fully recommend this game to anyone looking for a great time with a few friends.

     The idea is simple, be the first to 10,000 and you win. How you go about getting there is another story. You are a bunny and can either hop around following or disobeying orders as you see fit. You will receive orders from whoever is operating the "Robot". If you should choose to do so at any point and are able, you can take over running the robot which will lead to quicker point accumulation.

     I started with the tutorial and then played a round against the bots. I then repeated the above and thought I had it all figured out and was ready for my first game with real players... Boy was I wrong. There is a lot of things not included in the tutorial which you need to pick up in live games with real players. Games with bots (at this point) really aren't the same as with live players. Keeping in mind the game is still in early access, there aren't always a lot of players available for games all the time. The developer (Dez) is around and if he is free, he spends time teaching new players what to do in the game. There is a spectator mode where you can hear the players speaking over the mic and fly around anywhere in the level observing what is going on and I fully recommend taking advantage of this feature.

     The game is very polished in its current state and with Dez continuing with updates and hopefully adding new features this game promises to be great when it makes it out of early access. Maybe new animals which have unique abilities and different game modes (I think that I was already introduced to a new game mode during the last event) will make this game even greater than it already is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043909687', 'num_games_owned': 3884, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1449465784}
review:
As of today December 2, 2015, Obey is in Early Access but it's already fully functional. The various in-game rules are what's left to be finished, but you can enjoy the game already. Its weakness tho is that it's online only, and although there are bots, they are mostly to fill servers up, and so playing with them alone is not viable.

Obey is simply a game about power. Big deal, you might think, any videogame involves power. True, but Obey pares it down to its most important aspects: what one does to acquire and maintain it, and what other people have to deal with. Due to this, the game is designed to be played live against other people, and there's no single player. Although there are bots, they are mostly to fill servers up, and so playing with them alone is not viable.

Every players starts being "created equal", as a harmless bunny capable of little more than carrying and dropping items, and you mission is to amass a pre-determined amount of cash. Somewhere nearby them is a massive, weaponized tower, as the stand-in for Authority. It's the prime source of cash, and it makes itself felt in that most primal form possible: violence. Oh, and of course, only one lucky rabbit gets to control over. You can see where this is going.

The player commanding the tower (Robosaru) can just plain kill every other bunny with little effort... except there's no point in that, as they can work for him and help him get money faster. Either with the threat of violence or financial incentives, the enemy bunnies are exploited in order to make the Robosaru player richer. But of course, that player most likely won't rule forever, and can lose his Authority if he doesn't pay enough attention to hi unwilling subjects.

And here we have the most interesting part. Each bunny not already in the Robosaru can choose to be a loyal little worker, or try to sabotage and overthrow him. Players who choose the latter can skulk around the map and use various items to hamper the ruling bunny's flow of riches, and similarly, loyalists might get a reward by acting against a rebel. Or he might not. It's all up to the Robosaur's occupant, really. He can be ruthless or relatively benevolent, and the other bunnies might exploit that.

Because of this social element, voice chat is very important (altho players can use text messages), allowing the ruler to better express his wishes, and other bunnies to ask for favors. It might not look like much, but these conversations are essential to keep the game dynamic, and not allowing a single player to hog the Robosaur. Add to it a variety of items (laser fences, landmines, ammo for the Robosaur etc.) and the power relations can get complex.

It's only real drawback at the moment are the lack of players, but that's something that ebbs and flows. Overall, a very clever experiment on powermongering.

review: First of all, you need to understand the game before you start enjoying it. At first it may seem a bit boring and you may be wondering what to do. I would definitely recommend leaching on to an experienced player so that they can show you the ropes. There are a lot of tactics and things you may not realise you can do at first which will effect the score drastically. The idea of the game is to earn points and the highest score wins the round. You can either be a bunny or a robot although I never hot a chance to be a robot as it seems to be quite difficult to become the robot. As a bunny you can either obey the robot and follow its commands or you can rebel and try and knock points from the robots total. The robot can blast you to smithereens with a variety of arsenal so you risk certain death rebelling. I really enjoyed the bright colourful graphics and the sounds, especially the explosions. The bunnies are very cute if not a bit stupid and slow. I would have liked the bunnies to be a bit more agile to give a better chance of avoiding gun fire. I enjoyed the game and enjoyed playing with other people. You get a sense of teamwork whilst plotting against the robot. I would of course welcome achievements and trading cards and a one player option but this is a multiplayer game at heart and I would recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042838346', 'num_games_owned': 5513, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1498256942}
review:
[i]Développé par un seul homme, Obey entend faire vivre aux joueurs une expérience inédite en leur donnant un choix simple mais pourtant complexe : obéir ou désobéir ? Pour gagner il faudra manipuler les autres joueurs et réussir à les contraindre à œuvrer pour notre compte. Ce concept ambitieux sur le papier est-il aussi réussi une fois entre les mains des joueurs ? [/i]

Obey est un jeu multijoueur riche et complexe qui nécessite un temps d'apprentissage avant de pouvoir être pleinement apprécié. Un tutoriel détaillé (et en français) est le bienvenu et permet de familiariser le joueur avec les règles de base du jeu et avec les objets qu'il pourra utiliser lors d'une partie. Malgré tout c'est en jouant et en se confrontant à de vrais joueurs que l'on comprendra pleinement l'utilité de tous ces items et le potentiel stratégique du jeu. 

Vous commencez l'aventure en tant qu'un petit lapin, fragile et vulnérable face à l'énorme robot qui surplombe le terrain. Après une course contre les autres lapins pour s'emparer du puissant robot vous allez devoir, si vous échouez à mettre la main sur ses commandes, vous plier à ses ordres. Pour gagner il vous faut atteindre 10 000 pièces que vous obtiendrez en récoltant les objets déposés par le vaisseau et en les apportant dans la boîte du robot. Selon le bon vouloir de ce dernier vous serez payés 25,50,75 ou 100 pièces par objet. Obéissez et travaillez pour le robot ou alors essayez de le renverser en entrant par la porte en dessous de lui. Lorsque vous entrez dans le robot vous gagnez plus d'argent et vous pouvez manipuler les lapins pour que ceux-ci travaillent pour vous tout en se combattent entre eux. La manipulation est au cœur du jeu et à ces fins il est quasiment impossible de jouer sans micro. Il faut que les joueurs communiquent et élaborent des stratégies pour que tout cela soit intéressant.   

Pour commencer passons en revue les objets qui seront utilisables durant une partie. [list]
[*] [b]Mines[/b] : Uniquement visibles par le robot une fois placées par un lapin, elles tueront toutes les petites bêtes s'en approchant.
[*] [b]Capteurs[/b] : Les capteurs alertent le robot lorsqu'un lapin passe à proximité.
[*] [b]Collier[/b] : Chaque lapin qui porte un collier est facilement identifiable par le robot grâce à l'icône orange au dessus de lui. Celui qui n'en porte pas peut être considéré comme dangereux puisqu'il pourra tenter une évasion. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=569353472 En le portant le lapin gagne plus d'argent à chaque objet déposé dans la boîte du robot mais il est aussi très facile à éliminer car ce dernier peut auto-détruire les colliers. De plus, un lapin ne pouvant que porter trois objets au total, le collier qui compte déjà pour un objet lui demandera de faire plus d'allers-retours stock-boîte. 
[*] [b]Pointeur[/b] : Utilisé par un lapin il permet de pointer une position au robot. Idéal pour les filous qui font une alliance avec le robot et qui veulent dénoncer les lapins qui tentent de sortir des sentiers battus.
[*] [b]Lampe[/b] : La lumière de ces lampes rendra la tâche plus difficile aux lapins qui tentent une évasion.
[*] [b]Murs laser[/b] : Une fois placés ces murs grillent tous les lapins qui les touchent. [/list]
Tous ces objets ne sont utilisables que par les lapins qui vont les placer pour faciliter leur avancée en mettant des bâtons dans les roues des autres ou alors pour se faire bien voir aux yeux du robot et obtenir une récompense pécuniaire pour bon comportement. C'est au robot qu'incombe la tâche de faire obéir ses sbires, à lui de forger une alliance pour que ces objets lui soient utiles mais les lapins peuvent aussi décider de s'en servir de leur plein gré, les uns contre les autres.

Il existe d'autre part des objets que vous pourrez vendre en déposant dans la boîte du robot. Ces objets ont tous différents prix et bien que vous pourrez aussi vendre les objets évoqués ci-dessus, ceux que je m'apprête à évoquer sont uniquement à usage du robot. Celui-ci peut en commander et attendre que les lapins les lui remettent. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=569353532 [list]
[*] [b]Uranium[/b] : Un objet basique qui rapportera jusqu'à 100 pièces au lapin et 300 pour le robot.
[*] [b]Carburant[/b] : Ce carburant permettra d'alimenter le lance-flammes du robot.
[*] [b]Roquette[/b] : Le robot pourra tirer des roquettes destructrices sur les pauvres lapins. 
[*] [b]Batterie[/b] : Si le robot dispose de batteries il pourra activer les sentinelles qui électrocuteront les lapins s'approchant de sa porte. [/list]
Remarquez l'ironie dans le fait que vous fournissez vous-même au robot des armes qui pourront être retournées contre vous.

Le robot dispose de diverses commandes qui lui permettront de donner des avertissements aux joueurs ou de les payer. Pour éviter de devoir payer individuellement chaque lapin qui apporte des objets il peut mettre en place un paiement automatique (visible par le nombre de flèches vertes au dessus de la boîte, une flèche égale 25 pièces). Il doit toujours être vigilant et surveiller les lapins qui évoluent à ses pieds pour éviter d'être renversé.

Obey étant un jeu très riche je ne pourrais pas parler de toutes les stratégies possibles mais voici un avant-goût de ces possibilités.[list]
[*] [b]Lapins VS Lapins[/b] : Les lapins s'occupent d'acheminer les objets vers la boîte du robot et devront se méfier les uns des autres car leur paye peut être volée lorsqu'elle apparait ! Ils pourront placer des pièges pour éliminer des adversaires et œuvrer chacun pour leur propre compte.
[*] [b]Lapins VS Robot[/b] : Les lapins peuvent faire une alliance et se liguer contre le robot en effectuant des actions qui lui porteront préjudice au niveau financier (faire crasher le vaisseau contenant les objets que le robot a achetés, placer le corps d'un lapin dans la boîte, éteindre la centrale électrique du robot...etc). http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=561909620 [*] [b]Alliance lapin-robot[/b] : Un lapin peut demander de l'argent en échange de renseignements. Il va donc dénoncer tout lapin fuyard et avertir le robot lorsqu'un lapin s'approche de sa porte. [/list]
Il existe bien d'autres stratégies qui seront surtout réalisables à l'aide d'un micro comme leurrer le robot en criant qu'un lapin s'approche de sa porte et ainsi s'échapper lorsque son attention est détournée...etc. Les seules limites sont votre imagination et votre machiavélisme. 

Graphiquement parlant, le jeu est simple mais pas vilain du tout. Les lapinous sont adorables et paraissent réellement minuscules face à cet imposant robot. Le thème musical du jeu est vraiment bon mais la musique, absente lors des parties, manque réellement et permettrait d'accentuer l'ambiance de tension qui règne. Toutefois n'oublions pas que le jeu est toujours en accès anticipé et que ce genre de choses peuvent encore être améliorées.

Vous l'avez compris, le potentiel stratégique d'Obey est grand et fait de lui un jeu riche, complexe et très agréable à jouer lorsque l'on trouve des joueurs en ligne. Car c'est bien là son problème, il y a peu de joueurs en ligne et il reste à l'heure actuelle assez compliqué de se rendre compte du plein potentiel du jeu au vu de la fréquentation de ses serveurs. Malgré tout, Obey est déjà très complet et prometteur pour un jeu en accès anticipé et on voit directement que le développeur a été ambitieux en réalisant un tel projet basé sur la psychologie et la manipulation entre joueurs. Un projet qui aura clairement besoin d'une communauté pour vivre.

Short story: Yes, yes, yes. Great idea, great execution, great fun! Best EarlyA game I've played so far!
*** Note: Headset strongly recommended! ***

Well here we have an Early Access game that acually feels finished and bug-free! And the store page doesn't lie: Obey is unlike any other game.

It's a bizarre marriage of co-op and PvP at the same time - and it's hell of fun! It's both fooling around, and trying to win. Although the mechanics are fairly simple, and kind-of "easy to learn, difficult to master", there is no single "will always work", golden road to victory - depending on the situation, different strategies can work.

Simply put, being a good bunny earns you cash, being the boss earns you more. Any bunny can be boss - if you manage to enter the "bosstower" alive! Bunnies make cash by feeding items to a dropbox, and can hurt the boss by feeding it trash. So you have to be a smart boss, or the bunnies will ruin you. On the other hand, the boss has a chaingun. As a bunny, your only weapon is: acting smart. If you are a smart bunny, you might win even without being the boss.

The first player to reach $10.000 wins. All this, while voice-chatting with the others.

It's about timing (but not FPS reflexes), and knowing when to work together, and when to screw the others - and about the enjoyment while doing so :) Sneaking up on the boss is so much fun, as is fooling around with other bunny mates, trying to steal their pay...

I wish there was a free demo, everyone should try this!
Highly playable, I didn't encounter any bug so far.

review:
Let's see, Obey is a multiplayer game in which bunnies compete against each other for making the most money. Meanwhile, there's a giant robot -which is controlled by one of the bunnies- that "employs" the rest of the bunnies. The player can choose to obey the robot or try to overtake his or her position. So basically that's the concept. 

I had to play the tutorial a few times just to learn the ropes, because there are quite a few mechanics and I'm not used to multiplayer-only games... and then I found out that there weren't any players online. This has happened the three times I've tried the game, but I may have had bad luck. Luckily, there's a bot system that works pretty decently, so it's not like you can't play... but it's certainly not the way the game was meant to be played, I guess. 

It's kind of fun though. The game itself is based on a cool idea and the implementation is not bad. The graphics are also quite outstanding for an indie game, I specially liked the robot. The way the giant robot looks from the point of view of our bunny is truly imposing.

The price is still quite expensive in my opinion, but once it gets a proper sale price, I guess it would be really cool to play this game with a few friends after buying the 4-Pack. 

And well, I'm not sure what other features will be implemented in the future, but the game is quite playable already. I would like, for example, to have a sprint key or being able to hide the bunny underground or something. I haven't played for too long and I already felt it was sometimes too repetitive to go from one place to another carrying stuff just to be annihilated the moment I stepped out of the "delivery path" (yup, the bots are pretty smart)

I also think it would be cool if the robot had some kind of massive speaker and if it gave its orders through pre-recorded audio, rather than text. I think that would be a cool way to implement a bit more of humour into the game and for players to understand the game earlier. I mean, if I had heard "Bring me more uranium, or die!!!!!" I would have known right away what I had to do. The bots kind of already do that already through text, but I'd like to see it more often and, if possible, with audio. Just some suggestions. 

I'll definitely come back once more things are added to the game. Specially recommended to those that really enjoy multiplayer games in which you have to interact a lot with other players, be aware though that there aren't too many people online, so be sure to bring your friends with you!

review:
Obey is a multiplayer strategy game in which the player that reaches a certain amount of money (usually 10000) wins. To do that you can either obey the overlord and get rewarded for well-behaving (though that depends on how generous the current overlord is) while you slowly earn money, or overthrow the overlord, become the new ruler, earn money faster and turn the rest of the players into your lackeys.

This game is really funny (especially when you play it with people) and has a very unique concept, though there are a few things I'd recommend to any first-timer:

- Play the tutorial and then read [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446839914]this guide[/url]. The game itself has a steep learning curve and ignoring the tutorial will make it harder to get used to the mechanics.
- Use a microphone. This game requires a lot of social interaction and, while you can use a keyboard to send messages, it's way easier and more comfortable to just talk. Also you can't shoot down rebels while typing =P

In short, if you like strategy games based on social interaction then this game is perfect for you.

review:
Few things you need to know before you get into this game:
[list]
[*]Multiplayer only.
[*]You do want to play it with friends.
[*]Headset/microphone is highly recommended.
[/list]
This game is nothing like I’ve ever played before. You either play as a harmless bunny or a killer robot. 

As a robot you command a bunch of bunnies (vocally or via text/on-screen commands). Bunnies have to bring you (robot) ammo, fuel, batteries, etc and do tasks like building defenses around you. You reward them by paying salary. 

As a bunny you must [b]obey[/b] your robot overlord… or not. Robot has a “money generator” and you can sabotage robot’s income by turning generator off. There are other ways to ruin robot’s day. Most importantly, if you are sneaky enough, you can get inside the robot yourself and become the new overlord :) If you don’t obey and act fishy robot will send you to sweet bunny heaven in an instant. 

It is a roleplaying game in sense that everyone has to play a role (there is no inventory, experience or anything like that). Quality of gameplay highly depends on the ability of players to be able to embrace their roles. Headset certainly makes communication more fun. 

I applaud the developer for trying something unique rather than using Unity engine to make another minecraft clone and I do hope this game becomes successful enough for the servers to get populated. At this moment community is very small and there are barely any people playing. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Very unique concept. 
[*]Good visuals and sound. 
[*]Friendly community and developer.  
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]No singleplayer (playing with bots is pointless).
[*]Amount of “fun” depends on who you play with. 
[*]Not enough players at the moment.

review:
OBEY is a really unique multiplayer game that's quite difficult to describe really. In each match you start off by playing a Bunny and in the arena there is a large looming tower that can be controlled by one player. You have a choice as to how you choose to play. The player who controls the tower issues commands to the other players and then they can choose whether or not you want to obey (hence the name!) those commands or not. You might want to obey the commands from the tower and play the game that way, or you might try to rebel and take over the tower! 

The game play is very strategic, especially if you manage to get control of the tower. There are a ton of items in the game arena that can be used in different ways and add a huge amount of depth to the game. You'll certainly need to play through the tutorial but this isn't enough really. This is still in Early Access so hopefully the tutorial will be expanded in the future but in the meantime I'd recommend watching some Youtube videos to get a better idea of how it works.

You can play on a LAN using a private server or you can join an online one. When I tested it there were only a handful of empty servers online so hopefully more people will pick this up and the servers will become more populated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961138963', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1448425034}
review:
My first reaction when entering the game: "WTF?!"  If there was ever a game that WTF could summarize a first impression, this would be it. But not necessarily in the way one might expect.

My "WTF" moment wasn't due to anything offensive nor was it due to nonsensical or buggy content. In fact, there's nothing offensive in it, no gore, no bad language. There are  no noticeable bugs, no fps drops, no graphic glitches or crashes.  Instead, my immediate WTF reaction was due to just how bizarre and unique this game is compared to anything else I've ever played...and that's a GOOD thing.

You are one of many in an army of bunnies, attempting to cleverly outwit both other bunnies and the "master" bunny (who takes control of a giant, stationary yet deadly robot of death). The object of the match is to merely end up with more cash than your peers. You can do the master bunny's bidding and get paid for the tasks he creates to be completed or become the "master" bunny yourself and control the deathbot (which earns you cash more quickly).

Do you simply do what you are told and hope the other bunnies' greed will set them back? Do you work with a buddy to overtake the others and eventually, take control of the giant bot?  Are you willilng to backstab the others or do you insist on working as a team? Do you complete the assigned tasks to gain trust and favor from the mighty bot of doom all the while formulating and employing a master plan to overtake him and weilding the mighty power for yourself?  And if you do take control, who do you trust? Are you paying handsomely for the tasks to be completed to gain favor from your underlings even if it means they may start to catch up monetarily? Are you able to notice when a bunny starts to plot against you? Do you destroy the resistence with your mega machine gun or fry them with nepalm?  All questions that you'll be faced with in this game.

Despite it's cutesy look, it's a very deep, strategic game.

There is a lot of potential here. It's still in early access. Stability wise it seems solid. I think the tutorial could use some help as right now it's more of a text based instruction and it's difficult to remember what everything is and how to use them. There's no much in way of strategy guidance either.

The biggest criticism from me about its current state is the lack of consistent players online at any given time. The weekends seem to be more active of course, but during the week, good luck finding anyone online...at all.

I think easing new players into the game better will retain them. I think better marketing will open up the game's demographic. And if that happens, I think this little gem has the potential to be a sleeper hit.

review:
[b]Como dice arriba es análisis de acceso anticipado[/b]

[b]En pocas palabras:[/b] Si hay algo que define a un buen juego es la diversión y sobretodo cuando es compartida. Y este juego lo logra a las mil maravillas, por encima parece ser simple, apoderarse del robot y mantener a raya a los conejitos para obtener más ingresos y ganar, pero en el fondo hay mucho más pues no se trata de tener más puntería sino de tener cerebro para colaborar, liderar, manipular, engañar y sacar partido de cada acción que realicen los jugadores incluyéndonos. Este aspecto de interacción social a través del micrófono, chat y ordenes en el juego, es lo que lo hace tan divertido. Si bien la curva de aprendizaje puede ser algo lenta con el tiempo se va ganando la confianza para ser estratégicos al momento de jugar.

En el aspecto técnico el juego esta muy bien y no me ha presentado errores a pesar de ser de acceso anticipado. El diseño es simple pero bueno, el sonido cumple su función y los menús son claros en su mayoría. Jugando con teclado no tuve ningún problema y se comporto bien a nivel de FPS.

Este es un juego que todo el mundo debería probar alguna vez, puede que no les guste a todos, pero a los que sí, les gustara muchísimo, y quedaran enganchados.

[b]Pros:[/b] La mecánica de juego es increíble, mezcla elementos de shooter (podemos dispararle a los conejitos), estrategia (se debe gestionar nuestros recursos), rol-social (podemos asumir toda una actuación si queremos para interactuar con los otros jugadores), teniendo en cuenta que cada juego es siempre distinto porque depende de las acciones de los jugadores.

El desarrollador esta muy comprometido con el juego y la comunidad alrededor de este, así que es seguro que el juego terminara muy pulido y con grandes mejoras a parte de las que ya tiene.

[b]Contras:[/b] Al ser un juego que requiere interacción social es obligatorio tener la capacidad de poder tratar con otros, y en ese sentido a veces es posible que encontremos barreras como el idioma.

Lastimosamente hay poca gente jugandolo ahora mismo pero supongo que va a ser algo que cambiara con el tiempo, porque sin gente no hay juego (se puede jugar con bots pero no es lo mismo).

review:
[h1]Should You Buy This Game?[/h1]
OBEY is a very fun cooperative (or should I say uncooperative) multiplayer game. I originally had mixed feelings about this game due to a relatively poor tutorial, but once I managed to understand how OBEY is truly played, it became a blast. The two-faced style of gameplay can lead to some hilariously memorable moments. A couple words of advice before purchasing this game. The player base is still relatively small, and that is something that can only be remedied with you and your friends’ help. The purchasing format heavily discounts a 4-pack purchase. If you decide to go in on OBEY, I would recommend getting some friends in to help with a 4-pack purchase.

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
----11/25/2015----
There are two positions you may take part of when starting the game. You may play as a cute little bunny, scheming, plotting and looking for ways to overthrow the evil overseer controlling the robot of doom while maintaining a very obedient front in order to survive. Alternatively, you may play as the evil overseer controlling the robot of doom ensuring that those lying little devious monsters do your bidding. The main actions that the robot can take include killing the bunnies, deactivating hidden mines to help the bunnies stay alive, change pay scales in order to incentivize the bunnies to give you certain supplies (needed for ammo/security) etc. The main actions that the bunnies can perform include purchasing and feeding supplies to the robot, setting up security for the robot, warning the robot of bunnies making a break for the robot control room, or make a break for the robot control room.

Coordinating is much easier using a microphone. Although there are forms of communication without it, warning the robot of bunny locations can be difficult.

[h1]Current State of the Game[/h1]
There were no noticeable bugs found in my short play through, however there are couple important suggestions I feel if implemented will help improve the gameplay.

[b]Suggestions:[/b]
