review:
For an early access multi-player only game, I think this game has huge potential. 

There is a learning curve to understanding every concept that it throws at you. You can either play in this huge bot that can ask the bunnies running around to OBEY and trust you, so you won't shoot them. But they can also lie to you and trick you into thinking they will help you and take over the robot. 

The whole goal is to get to 10,000 points, depending on how you pay out using the robot or by getting paid as a bunny on the battlefield; it can get really tricky. Using a microphone is part of getting the most out of this game, since you can talk to everyone on the server and potentionally give them tasks or they can tell you something, and bamn, they either will subvert you or go with what you ask. But only one player can win, and that is whoever achieves 10,000 points. 

I recommend this game with a small con against it, it's tutorial is simple and may need more polishing and a little more handholding to give you a better understanding of the game before you start playing on a live server. It tries to break down what each mechanic does, but it's not in depth. This is a social game and you can play with bots, but the most fun is when playing with real players. 

The game also has it's charm, since you can either play a bunny or a huge bot that kills the bunnies or helps them. Overall I think with some more polish on the tutorial and a bigger player-base this game has all the qualifications of a fun multi-player only game. 

Also Dez (the developer) really wants to help the community either learn his game and/or get feedback to better his game and get the most out of his project. I will definitely be coming back to this game as more patches and more content gets in place. I would love to try a new tutorial when Dez has time to work on it.

review:
OBEY is truly a great game. It has one of the best concepts in a game that I have ever seen - it just needs polishing. As with most indie multiplayer-only games (there are bots but the experience is not the same), it is often difficult to find a match when it has just joined the market recently and is early in development. But I can say the games I have played were very fun. I've only had it for 2 days and have played 10+ hours already.

The main objective of the game is to earn the most money, and whoever gets to $10000 (default) first wins the match. Each person controls a bunny, and one player controls the robot (or "robosaru"). The robot has a range of weapons and must force the bunnies to give him more ammo, more money or snitch on other players in return for cash. The robot however earns cash must more quickly and easily than the bunnies, so to prevent them form winning the bunnies must try to sneak into the robot's door and take it over without the robot noticing.

There are much more elements of this game that play large roles in deciding who wins, such as lying, deception and other psychological and game aspects.

The game has quite a steep learning curve, and the tutorial is not very clear, but the developer (who seems very nice ;) ) is often on the servers teaching people how to play and develop strategies. That's how I learnt anyway.

The game does recommend a microphone, but so far I've done quite well without using mine all the time - maybe only using it once or twice to give long commands.

One big issue I have been having is the game having a 19/20 chance of crashing when i connect to a server. This has been found to be a problem with unity and the dev says if they do not fix it soon then he will make a workaround.

Definately consider buying this game, or at least following it to see how it develops :)

review:
[h1]Be ready to control bunnies![/h1]

This is a very unique multiplayer game. You are a bunny, that is trying to gain control over a huge dictating robot on the map. Once in control you try to convince other "bunnies" (players) to follow your orders. You win by collecting the most money.  But beware for some bunnies might disobey you and will try to take control over the robot themselves, so be on your guard. 

Any bunny can take control over the robot, by just entering the front door, but when you control the robot, you have a few weapons at hand to protect yourself, like a flamethrower, sentries and a minigun. The downside is that other bunnies supply you with ammunition for these weapons.

It doesn't mean that you can only win the game by entering the robot, you can even win by never setting foot in it, by cleverly picking what materials to deliver to the feed box. Not every player that controls the robot is vicious or cruel, some might rule with a benevolent spirit and choose to share the wealth with the hardworking bunnies. That's what makes every game completely different and utterly fun.

This game has so much depth, just writing a mere review doesn't do it justice, it should be experienced from first hand by playing.

This game is just a big mindfak. Who can you trust?

+ Every new game is different

[h1]Обзор:[/h1]

По смыслу очень простая игра: есть мультиплеерная сессия, побеждает набравший самое большое количество очков (в данном случае - денег). Самый козырный способ это сделать - сидеть в большом роботе (у вас увеличенный прирост очков и несравнимая с прочими игрокам в данный момент огневая мощь). 

В роботе вы можете заставить (предложить) других игроков работать на вас, прочих можете убивать. И получать автоматическую прибыль от электростанции.

Вне робота вы можете сжигать предметы, разбросанные по игровому полю, в печке, получая очки. Или попытаться занять место того, кто в роботе.

[h1]Оценка:[/h1] 

6.3/10

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1] 

[olist]
    [*]Конфетно-карамельная графика (правда кое-где есть мутные текстуры, но в целом выглядит симпатично)
    [*]Хороший перевод на русский язык. Спасибо разработчикам! Очень уважаю, когда они заботятся не только об англо-говорящих людях
    [*]Оригинальная идея
[/olist]

[h1]Не понравилось в игре самое главное - геймплэй:[/h1]

[olist]
    [*]Вы выполняете тупую работу по набору очков. Я лично люблю в мультиплеерных играх сам процесс игры, мне не интересно, сколько кто набрал очков.
    [*]У всех персонажей кроме того, кто в роботе - очень мало возможностей: вы можете медленно перемещаться по игровому полю и носить по 3 предмета - всё.
    [*]Я не люблю подчиняться. Если в мультиплеерной игре у удного из игроков заведомо есть чудовищное преимущество перед вами, то это просто начинает раздражать.

[h1]Резюмирую:[/h1]

Садясь за игру в свободное время хочется одного - получить удовольствие от процесса. Мои друзья ценят в играх примерно то же самое, поэтому я не думаю, что игра понравится и им. Исходя из этого, я не рекомендую "OBEY". Но если вы всё же решились её приобрести - берите "4-Pack" и раздате друзьям. Вместе вам однозначно будет веселее.

review:
Early Access Review, 11/21/15

[b]Short Version:[/b] Unusual multiplayer game featuring diplomacy and negotiation alongside stealth and strategy.  Conversing with your opponents is practically required, so beware purchasing if your rig lacks a mic or you don't enjoy, you know... talking.  Otherwise, have fun playing as Little Bunny FooFoo hopping through the forest, jumping into the giant killer robot of doom and extorting money and guns from all your little bunny friends via bribery and threats of flamey death! 

OBEY is a remarkably strange, fascinating game with a steep learning curve.  The tutorial is an absolute must, and even that doesn't cover all the tactics involved - although hopefully this will be improved before the game's final release.  The game is also multiplayer only, so if you prefer sticking to single player games, you can skip this game (and the rest of this review).

Remember those "friendly"(ha!) tabletop sessions of Risk where you tried to convince good ol' Bob spread across Asia that it was completely in his own interest to invade Canada in order to wipe out Evil Overlord Fred, all while you hunkered down in Austraila peacefully hoarding billions of troops to win you the game a few turns later?  Or that one game of Monopoly where you convinced your little sister that giving you a monopoly on Boardwalk and Parkplace in return for Reading Railroad would actually win HER the game in the end?

Well, OBEY is just that; a game of dirty diplomacy and friendly manipulation.  In OBEY, your goal as a tiny, cute little bunny rabbit is to take control of a giant deadly robot with laser-eyes and a flamethrower, then somehow convince all the other tiny, cute - and extremely treacherous - little bunny rabbits that feeding you the money you need to win and the weapons you need to kill them dead is definitely a good idea.

The gameplay smushes together stealth, observation, strategy, and game theory into a 3D world populated by you and all your bunny rabbit friends waddling slowly around and trying to make money, along with one giant killer robot with laser eyes of doom who can make money faster than anyone.  The robot can be taken over by anyone who sneaks inside, but it can also lay the smack down on any bunny who twitches their nose the wrong way -, or 'generously' pay an allowance to the bunnies who play nicely.   To win, you must pay close attention to your surroundings and what every other player is up to, negotiate with - and lie to - other players , and above all not aggravate the giant robot with laser eyes of doom before you can shuffle your cuddly little bunny butt inside to kick out the current occupant and take it over.

All in all, if you have a microphone and sometimes like thinking, strategizing, and negotiating in your games instead of the usual run-n-gun, I recommend you give this quirky game a shot.  However, this comes with a strong 'buyer beware': as with any multiplayer game, enjoyment depends on the people you play with, so you will need to bring friends or be OK relying on random strangers (who hopefully speak your language and have mics of their own).  

---

Note:   Due to the social nature of the game, you may want to split a 4-pack with friends.  If that doesn't work for you, at least the developer seems to be quite active and doing his best to help people learn the game, so it seems likely that even games with strangers will be fun.   Of course, keep in mind that OBEY is in Early Access, so it is difficult to tell how popular it will be down the line, and how easy it will be to find quality random matches.  Thus, your final mileage may vary.

Note 2:  The giant killer robot of doom may not actually have laser eyes.  But it should.

review:
OBEY is a unique multiplayer game where there are a bunch of bunnies and one bunny that controls a giant robot. The way you win is by earning cash, by controling the robot, or obeying the robot and they pay you. As the bunnies you go around, collecting and building for the robot. However, you can do stuff to lower the robots score if you dont get caught like dropping corpses in the delivery box. You can also take over the robot, if they dont notice you. However, if the Robot does see you, they can kill you. 

Now as the Robot, your job is to keep your bunnies in check. You can see them if they are wearing a collar, if not you will want to keep and eye on them. You have various weapons on your robot, a giant gun, rockets and a flamethrower. All which require ammo that your bunnies, must bring to you. You buy items via a drop ship, be warned tho bunnies can make it crash so make sure its all ready in its landing phase before you fill it up. author: {'steamid': '76561198051833438', 'num_games_owned': 6279, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1466185693}
review:
[i]I received this game for free from the developer for the purposes of review [/i]

I don't think I can categorize this game into a genre, I haven't played many like it
I guess it may resemble arena games a little; the game requires a mix of social skills, strategy and decision making, although a bit of luck won't hurt.

In this game, you're mostly a small rodent - except when you aren't. Your purpose in the scary little world you're in is to follow orders - except when you'd rather not. Sounds a little confusing I suppose. But basically you could be an obedient little worker bee and keep big brother happy, or you could pretty much do anything you want as long as you don't get caught. Talking to the other players in this game is a big part of the experience, and the push to talk and push to mute options built into the game work very nicely. The atmosphere created by the dark environment, the flood lights, and the rodents fragility is Orwellian, I found myself thinking about old school Sci-Fi books. The Robot is a lot like big brother, something in the game also kept making me think of Asimov, though I'm not sure what. On the whole the game is very good at pulling you in, just alt tabbing from it feels like you're going to another world.

That said, it's not easy figuring out what you want to do in the game, and if you ignore the tutorial like I did (you really shouldn't), you'll just find yourself working like an obedient little sheep, and you'll miss out on all the hidden little things you can in the game. (Tip: try crashing the carrier, the little marshmallow in a campfire explosions are worth it)
Techinically the game has a goal and a win condition, but it's not enforced, and I like that.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Stable on PC and Mac
[*] Simple concept, very easy to get started in, but has a lot of fun little secrets to discover
[*] Nice Engine
[*] Nice sound and visual effects; great lighting
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] The tutorial failed to grab my attention.
[/list]

This is a social game, and if you're the kind of person who would rather play GMod, than solo grind a single player game, then you'll enjoy OBEY.

[b][h1]7/10[/h1][/b] a great game if you want to mess around with your friends.

review:
ok, i don't always make reviews on games, but, it's just amazing how much fun can you have in this game, there is such a great community!

but what is it all about? Well, it' a VERY asimmetrical game, with a lot of complex and original mechanics: 
you are a bunny, to win you have to make 10.000 cents, in each map in obey there's one robosaru, a HUGE robot/turret equipped with a machinegun, rocket launchers, and a flamethrower. when you enter the robot you earn 10 cents per second, when you're not in the robot, you earn 1 cent per second. any bunny can enter the robot at any time and take his place, by entering the door located exactly in front of him, so there will be a constant war between the bunnies trying to enter the robot, and the bunny inside the robot trying to defend himself.
As a robot you cant' just kill bunnies randomly, as you NEED them alive to drag and drop items into the ''feed box'', as it is the fastest way to earn money.
So, as a bunny inside the robot you have to create your ''dictatorship'' by controlling all the bunnies that they're doing their job, you can give them money, warnings, make them  wear the ''loyality collar'', wich will be always displayed in the HUD of the robot, to be sure of the positions of all the bunnies, and if they disobey, well, it's your choice >:D 
So the bunnies have to sneak very carefully from the working location to the robot's door without being caught if they want to became the ''bunnylord''.
There are another couple of mechanics that i didn't explained, like the generator, the corpses, laserwalls...
but these are just the main lines of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000824354', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1466613976}
review:
A fairly unique multiplayer game of being a Bunny and trying to take control of a giant gun and earn power and money using a combination of honesty, deception, obedience, mutiny, servitude, manipulation, lying, cheating, stealing and all the other C.V. ruining human traits. It's the first Steam release from an American developer with a brief history in game art and development, and comes with a unique mix of gameplay elements which sometimes make for really interesting player interactions and psychological situations.

After playing for just a couple of days I found myself beginning to analyse people mid-conversation in my day to day life, wondering if they were lying to me about trivial things for monetary gain, half-expecting them to hide in a piece of furniture and rush at me when I wasn't watching. It's a game which undoubtedly gets in your head when you play too much.

Full disclosure: I have no affiliation with the developer, but did recieve a key.

Consisting of a medium sized map with up to 10 Bunny players, the sole objective in OBEY is to amass as much money as possible, but the methods for accomplishing this vary based on the current player:power scenario and can shift in an instant. One central gun/watchtower called the Robosaru exists per map, a Power Plant which generates money for the player inside the Robosaru, and a Feed Box where Bunnys can deposit items to generate money for the Overlord, and usually make money for themselves in the process.

Whoever commands the Robosaru has a distinct advantage in the form of 10x passive income, and of course deadly control, but it comes at the cost of everyone trying to steal that control either through direct attacks, or by lying, manipulating and sabotaging the Overlord or any combination of their fellow Bunnys in persuit of their own paycheck. Because it becomes increasingly difficult to watch more than a Bunny or two, the Overlord must work together to keep himself safe, similarly Bunnys want to stay alive and profit more, which means that the dynamics constantly change based on how many players are in the game, how much money they have, what they're assumed attitude towards each other is, and what they actually accomplish.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

At a higher level OBEY about out thinking your fellow players. In the early stages I routinely found myself asking for more money for performing actions, and being a sort of salesman for myself. When I learned that I could cheat my fellow Bunnys by lying about their actions, a new avenue of options opened up. This lack of strict limitation and the utility of psychological warfare via spoken commands and text brings the gameplay to a higher level than simply running around trying to earn money and directly sabotage the current winner, and it's where the game shines.

The visual style is also very worth pointing out. Maps tend to be very simple, and I personally love the low polygon approach to the assets. The animations and movement are also well correlated with the visuals, and having a group of Bunnys all turn their heads to stare at me in the hull of a gloomy-lit ambient Dropship ended up being far more creepy than it rightfully should've been.

[h1]Mistakes and Annoyances[/h1]

Being in Early-Access, technical issues are less of an issue and though I had a few small technical problems every single one of them was mentioned on the development panel as currently being worked on. There are still technical issues worth bringing attention to though, like lag and server drops which are common. The server console is fairly flat and bland and utilizes an IRC channel which comes with pros and cons, and the server client for hosting your own games is completely unmentioned in game, and I only found it through a mention on the website.
There's also a real lack of options for play just now. There are a handful of dedicated servers with various configurations, and each round has a small pool of maps to select from, but there's currently only a couple of US server and maybe a handful in the EU, so if your ping isn't particularly good you're probably going to be limited to a server or two at best, and if you're inexperienced or looking for different gameplay types, you're going to be waiting for far too long to connect to a good server.

Which brings up the biggest problem with this title: the lack of players. It's great fun when there are enough people around, and genuinely addictive and intense gameplay takes place, especially with people you know, but currently the community is only really palpable during a very specific set of hours and if you know more than a handful of players then you're unlikely to play with people you haven't mostly already seen. This wouldn't be a problem in most games, but here if you know what to expect from a player or they remember what you did the last few games, there's probably a disadvantage for one of you and a bias towards the same gameplay unfolding.

I expect this game to grow over time, and it's a game more than any other I've found that will become better with a larger community in place, so it's a real problem when there's no effort to grow the player base other than perhaps a Steam group and the developer forums. While the current community is definitely great fun to play with, and well in tune with the spirit of the game, it's still both drastically dependent upon, and lacking in players.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

You can pick up OBEY just now for £10.99/14.99€/$14.99 or your regional equivalent, and the 4-Pack option saves you a chunky 40% if you have a couple of friends. As with all multiplayer games, your value for money is subjective based on how much you're likely to play, but when compared to other popular multiplayer titles on Steam, this is priced on the higher end, though it doesn't have in-game purchases or DLC to worry about.

While finding people to play with can be an issue, if you expect the player base to grow then this is a fair buy, and good value for money if you go for the 4-Pack option. If you need a good multiplayer scene then you might want to wait til after release, for a sale, or until the player levels reach a better level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168987818', 'num_games_owned': 964, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1471794666}
review:
Obey - достаточно своеобразный проект в раннем доступе разработанный студией Dan Dez. Здесь мы окажемся в шкурах пушистых и белых кроликов.

Итак, в чем же весь смысл игры? Все просто, за сражения нужно набрать как можно больше золота. В этом не легком деле нам поможет большая пушка которая располагается по центру карты. Естественно тот кто доберется до пушки сможет творить, все что ему вздумается, а также будет получать в 10 раз больше золота. При большой огневой мощи орудия можем заставить работать весь остров на нас. Конечно кроля правителя можно свергнуть, и занять его удобное место, но это будет относительно сложно. Но ведь в этом и есть весь смысл игры.

Obey в первую очередь многопользовательская игра. Для более комфортного времяпровождение необходимо наличие 4-8 человек. Так вот, например, нам удалось стать правителем, что же нам делать? Чтобы обезопасить себя от нашествия недоброжелателей большую часть прибыли придется тратить на покупку оружия и ресурсов. Можно стать беспощадным правителем, что приведет к революции, а можем стать добрым, но тогда нами будет легко манипулировать. Поэтому будет сложно найти некую грань которая поможет нам оставаться у руля робота.

Что касается графики то можно наблюдать, что некоторые фрагменты прорисованы лучше других. В целом же все карты очень даже хорошо проработаны. Саундтрек отлично дополняет атмосферу игры.

В итоге разработчику отдадим должное, он проделал огромную работу. Сама идея проекта уникальна, есть возможность посмотреть кто и как управляет, у каждого человека свой подход к игре. Карты отлично сбалансированы, что позволяет легко ориентироваться лидеру, и руководить.  Если вы хотите испытать что-то новое то пожалуй вам стоит обратить внимание на данный продукт.

Плюсы
- Игра в раннем доступе
- Возможность играть по локальной сети
- Низкие системные требования
- Креативная игра
- Хорошее сообщество
- Наличие русского языка

Минусы
- Мало людей
- Цена немного завышена

7/10

*Для ознакомления с игрой, ключ предоставил разработчик.

review:
Envision a mix between a Free for all Gmod's Prison break and follow the leader, whereas disobediance means death. Obey seems to take the key components of each and effortlessly sews them into a mix of death, disaray, and deceit.  While early access should be considered a gamble, i judge this game with immediacy in mind; it being a complete experience in its current form.

The gameplay consists around each player starting as a meager rabbit vying for profit and the end goal of obtaining 10,000$ to win the game. Once the map has begun, the rush to robot occurs. The player who first makes it into the Robot will take control, thus begining his cycle of tyrany. From there, it is the other players goal to overthrow him by reaching the entrance of the robot and taking it for themselves. Both the rabbits and robot have have means to make or even steal money, so it may not be wise to emediatly bet all your eggs on making it to the robot.

In the means of presentation , the game consists of very fluent audio design with a pastel aesthetic to fit. In terms of performance, the game runs at a consistent 60fps (Likely currently capped, as i do not dip over or under). Currently there is not a large community that plays the game consistantly so finding a game may require so wait time and a bit of scheduling to get a larger game. Overall, this is a game i would advise anyone to atleast keep an eye on if you are into ideas as asymetry or deceit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069634986', 'num_games_owned': 3362, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1475921494}
review:
[b]OBEY[/b] is a game with a very interesting concept which I will describe in the next paragraph. It is entirely multiplayer as interaction with other players is crucial. It's unlike any other games I've played before and its concept is very well made.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

[h1]What is happening in the game:[/h1]
In OBEY, one player is a leader and controls all the other players from a giant robot. This robot has the ability to shoot bullets and rockets that kill the disobeying players, if the leader sees them and shoots them.
Other players, bunnies, have to listen to the leader. They have to wear tracking collars and carry weapons into the robot's feedbox. The leader pays them for that, but the point of the game is for the bunnies to sneak into the robot and take the leader's position. In other works, you have to obey until you have the chance to hide and sneak to the robot.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]An unique idea that is not just unique, but also well executed. It's very interesting to observe how different leaders have different approaches to controlling other and how players in control respond to their manipulation.
    [*]Maps are well-balanced as they allow the leader to control the players, but other players are still able to take over the leadership if they play well and have good tactics.
    [*]This game encourages interaction between players which includes giving orders, lying, deceiving and betraying other players for money.
    [*]The maps and objects look great. They are simple and modern-looking. Also, the soundtrack fits in very nicely.
    [*]The developer is active and is constantly making new updates to the game.
    [*]This game is also made for Linux and MacOS powered systems.
    [*]There is also a tutorial which explains step by step how things work by walking the player along different objects and stages of the game.
    [*]In case there is a lack of players online, you can also play via LAN.
    [*]Low system requirements.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]At certain hours, there might be a lack of online players. Mostly, however, you should be able to find a running game.
    [*][strike]Tags on Steam also include "Includes level editor", but can't seem to be able to find it anywhere.[/strike] Levels can be made using third-party software: [url=http://www.mapeditor.org/]link[/url]
    [*]Sometimes, it's hard to play when a leader is someone without a microphone. I don't know how the developer could fix it, though.
    [*]I feel like the price is a bit high, at least for the current amount of content. There should be more game modes, weapons and maybe some tools for the bunnies to handle, not only the leader. There is a 4-pack with much cheaper price per copy, however.
[/list]

[h1]Suggestions:[/h1]
More players would be much appreciated, but the game is never really discounted a lot. Bringing more players would bring some energy to the community and the developer would have a much easier time getting new ideas and improving the overall impression of the game.

[h1]The final verdict:[/h1]
The idea for this game is amazing and, in my opinion, it is worth supporting the developer, although the price is a bit high for the current amount of content. Interaction with other players adds a whole new level to player experience. This game is really great at making you think how to free yourself while not raising any suspicion and, when you manage to get in charge of the robot, you actually feel rewarded and accomplished.
The game is well made, still missing some options and players, but is overall in great shape. I certainly recommend it.

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

review:
Warning: MICROPHONE HEAVILY RECCOMENDED

Incredibly interesting game, just playing it is fun, once you understand that it is more of a social game frankly, though depending on who is the Robosaru you can also end up with the whole thing being a stealth game in avoiding being gunned down while trying to sneak up. The fun in this game is not necessarily in winning, but in actually playing it too, I feel proud even when I'm just in second or third place, which is perfectly okay with me, there's a few mechanics not explained in the tutorial though.

"Corpsing" is perhaps the most major mechanic, if you are killed by a laserwall or flames then you will leave a corpse, if you drop this corpse into the feederbox the robosaru will lose a fairly significant amount of money, so it gives incentive for the robosaru to be very careful, oh and it's also possible to destroy corpses by shooting them as the Robosaru, so you don't have to worry about a whole ton of rabbits running corpses constantly, though they probably will try to do so anyway if you give them reason to.

Collars increase your money gain per in-game tick from 2 to 6, and provided you have a kind but controlling overlord, also lets him/her keep easy track of where you are and, if particularly kind, the robosaru might even give you extra money for ratting out runners and such.

Playing the tutorial is heavily reccomended, and do also understand that other bunnies are also people, there will be assholes regardless of what you do.

The only negative point I have with this game is that, as a european player OUTSIDE of Germany, at the time of writing this, there does not seem to be a single other person in Europe playing this game that is not german/speaking only german and nothing else.

review:
What a great game! To become a decent player, you have to understand when to be a loyal bunny and when to revolt. How to take advantage of the terrain and the actions of the other bunnies to enact your revolution. How to keep track of your bunnies as an overlord, keeping them busy and earning you money, while simultaneously keeping an eye out for bad bunnies trying to subvert you. How to manage a corpse-factory, and how to hide weapons from the overlord.

To be a great player, you need to understand the different playstyles and behaviours of the other bunnies in your group. Is bunny A a generous or mean overlord? Are they a loyal bunny, or do they run away at the first opportunity? As an overlord, do they focus on the loyal bunnies, the feedbox, their door or the environment? What are their search-patterns? A great player knows how to take maximum advantage of the different personalities in the group.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050375616', 'num_games_owned': 3359, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1485871885}
review:
OBEY,
What an awesome game. I'll get this said early and go into more detail after.
If you like online multiplayer games and want to try one with a twist like no other. 
Then OBEY is a game worth picking up immediately.
I've been playing OBEY for 6-7 months now before it arrived here on Early Access on steam.
I have 100+ hours pre-steam at least. Its been one of the most enjoyable Indie, Alpha experiences I've had.
OBEY has a one man development power house. Who is passionate about his game. He works on fixes and has been updating the game often with fixes and balances pre-steam and that trend continues here on early access. I have seen this game grow into something incredible and its great to finally see it in a place where more will have access to it. 

Lets get onto the game and its mechanics.
OBEY IS an asymetrical multiplayer game. Its not skill based in the way that most multiplayer games are. Twitch reflexes wont help you here. Its more about working out your enemies strategies, their game plans while also working to control your opponents to make them obey you to help you win the game. 
I'll break it down more simply.
It works best 4-8 players in my opinion.
Its in a sense free for all. (altho an alliance system is planned for the future)
So you all start out as cute little bunnies. The goal of the game is to reach $10000 
As a bunny it is difficult to earn money. Thats ok because there is a appartment block sized robot in the map armed with a minigun the size of a school bus.
Now as the robot, which you can enter by walking in a door at its base you will earn money more quickly.
You can call a drop ship. Which will allow you to buy supplies to help you earn more money and defend yourself with ammunition and other items to help you keep control of the robot. The robot is only able to drop these supplies on the map. He has to get the other players to feed him these items. Which will take good leadership and control. A happy bunny is a less likely to subvert you. Now as a bunny. You can choose to either OBEY you're leader or Subvert him.

I have done some videos which will give you a better idea oh how this works. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=447068748

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=447068752

But yes if you wanna label an number score on it, It'd be 10/10 / 100% / 2 Thumbs Up.
Indie Game of The Year Contender.
This is even better with friends. 4 Packs are available and recommended in my opinion.
It works really well with strangers also. Its interesting working different people's strategies out. 

There is a detailed wiki and an active ever growing community.
Join us.
I OBEY you to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012009261', 'num_games_owned': 4766, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 2279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1678, 'last_played': 1593023085}
review:
[b]Robosuru is love...[/b]
[b]Robosuru is life...[/b]

This was a tale about a cute little bunny.
Him and his friends were out in the field one day. Wondering what the purpose of life even was.
Here they were, nomming on grass. And one little bunny wondered off curiously.
He then found what appeared to be a giant robot with an enormous minigun attached to the front. Along with that, arms that when given the correct resources will shoot out missiles. Oh.. And a fuel tank that when given fuel, can shoot out giant bursts of fire towards the given target, or in this case, bunny.
Anyways, back to the story.

This wondering bunny saw a huge metal door that had a little crack in the middle. He stepped on forward as the giant robots light was beaming down at him, making a loud noise. And as he curiously went into the little slit, he then began riding an elevator to the top of the Robot. He realized he was at the robots control center. He stepped up off of the elevator and onto the control platform. He then took control of the giant robot and looked around for his friends, he found them and commanded them to group up together in the middle of the field.
He then saw a button that was marked "Dropship = $$$$" and then he pressed it.
Upon pressing it he noticed a countdown timer starting from 60 seconds, he looked out into the horizons and saw a another beam of light. It was the dropship! He knew he could take advantage of this. He saw other buttons marking items to purchase. He bought a few collars to manage his friends as he took full control of the situation. He then bought uranium to make him some money. The dropship finally arrived after counting down from 60 and dropped loads of uranium down onto the middle of the field. The 'drop zone'.
He then ordered the bunnies to proceed loading the uranium into a glowing green box that was marked "Feed Box".
At first his old 'friends' refused. They wanted to be paid too.
So the bunny at first raised the auto-pay to 25%. 3 bunnies began loading. A fourth bunny refused to load any uranium unless he was given full pay. 
The overlord robo bunny denied the request, and instead killed him with the minigun and sent him to the dropship.
The bunny was angry and was wanted revenge.. In those 60 seconds of the dropship on it's way back to the dropzone to drop off more supplies, he plotted.. He plotted to uproot the overlord (his old best friend) and take over from there.
You may ask why..
Well. Nobody knows why.
It's just..
In their nature.

The robosuru bought the dropship rebel bunny a pointer and a collar. He offered a deal with the rebel who wanted full pay.
The deal was simple.
If the bunny would watch over the gate in case any other bunnies tried to subvert him, he would pay. Handsomely, might I add. Not as much as full pay, but a lot more than what the other bunnies were making.
The cute little bunny accepted this duty. He grabbed the pointer and put on the collar then went on to being just in front of the robot.
The overlord knew he should be trusted.. As he knew that the bunny would want to be paid more than the rest.
Little did the overlord know that the other bunnies could see just exactly how much money the overlord was making. They got really upset and demanded 75% autopay for turning in uranium and other supplies, such as fuel or rockets.
The robot gave them 75%. The guard bunny was mad at the auto pay and also noticed how quickly the robots money went up every second. By the hundreds.. Meanwhile he'd get paid only a fraction of what the robot made.
So the guard quickly made his way to the gate, only a few feet away and got in. "Yes! I subverted the bunny and now I can make a ton of money!" He said, actually squeaking down to the others. He then assumed position and control over the entire robot, the old bunny who was in charge now in the dropship, awaiting arrival.
The new overlord then said "You. In the drop ship. You will do EXACTLY what I say. No asking for better pay. You are mine now. I own you."
The bunny knew he didn't have any other choice. He went along with the other bunnies to load up uranium to the feed boxes. 4 bunnies loaded up uranium. Three came back to the drop zone. 1 took off his collar and loaded it into the feed box without the overlord noticing. 
Quickly the bunny who took off the collar ran out into the field while the overlord was watching over the three other bunnies;
He made his way to the front gate of the robot and stepped in.
Only for the cycle to begin once more...

author: {'steamid': '76561198146366619', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1662, 'last_played': 1449616510}
review:
OBEY is simply one of the best games i have played and it is only in Alpha. Words can't do justice for this game because you can't truly describe the simplistic complexity or bringing items from the drop off to the feed box. Regardless of where your standing is there is always an undercurrent of tension as you don't truly know who is winning until someone does. On top of the in general fear of the robo there is a fear of teamwork. You can make plans with someone just to have them stab you in the back for extra money. Likewise any comment made during the game could be truthful or a lie to try and get ahead. They could be warning you that someone is going to take control, or they could just be trying to distract you in order to make you lose. One game I decided I would respond to people pretending i was someone else. i ended up confusing the robo so much that on 9 different occasions he killed the player he thought was me and i ended up just getting farther ahead. This game has a somewhat steep learning curve but the entire community is incredibly helpful and new players are quickly acclimated to the sometimes hour long continuous power struggle that is OBEY.

P.S. If you're worried about the developer ditching the game, don't. Dez regularly plays online and he is constantly updating different aspects in order to keep the incredibly unbalanced game, balanced

author: {'steamid': '76561198017871005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1626312854}
review:
This game is occasionally compared to Town of Salem, in that the main draw of the game is the social aspect where you must manipulate other players and play the intellectual game in order to win.

The very start of a match involves a footrace where every player runs towards the giant robot at one side of the map.  The first person there takes over the robot and becomes the master.  Being the master can be a double-edged sword, because while you do make a ton of money, the bunnies under your heel have many ways to make you lose all of it very quickly.  The best part about this game is that it's very possible to NEVER be in the robot and still win.

One game I was playing, one player was in the robot for the majority of the game.  He had 8,000 points and climbing (you need 10,000 to win) while everybody else was at about 3,000 or less.  I spent some of my points to buy laser walls, an item that sets up a deadly trap that kills any bunny that touches it.  When my compatriots and I were delivered back to the game via dropship after being killed, two of my rivals foolishly decided to make a break for the robot.  While the robot was distracted with annihilating them, I ran into an area the robot couldn't see and set up my trap.

Now, the interesting part in this game is that a dead bunny's corpse significantly lower's the robot's score when delivered to the robot's delivery area.  The robot can get resources (missiles, flamethrower fuel) and points if bunnies deliver items there, but delivering a dead bunny lowers their score quite significantly.  I committed suicide on the trap I had set up outside of the robot's vision about half a dozen times, then delivered my bunny's charred remains over and over.  The guy that was moments away from winning and had been in the robot the entire game now had negative points and couldn't afford to bribe other players into doing his bidding.  Every single bunny in the game (except me) then spent their points to overload the dropship and crash it, which causes dead bunnies to spawn at random points on the map instead of being delivered to a fixed area (at least until the ship is replaced, which is expensive).  Now there was an uprising and the robot changed hands quite a few times.

Nobody found out about my trap and corpse-making machine.  Every single time someone new got in the robot, I destroyed their score and rose through the ranks until I was in the lead.  I never obeyed the robot but I never tried to take over either.  I ended up winning that particular match because I kept committing suicide over and over, then pulling off heists and stealthily avoiding the robot's gaze.

No other game I've ever played offers an experience like that.  This game is phenomenal, and the developer regularly logs in to teach new players about the game (he's also an evil dictator when he's in the robot, don't listen to him).  I highly recommend anybody that's interested in a more intellectual and socially interesting game to give it a try.

review:
And no, the Overlord is not overpowered. Well he is kinda, but you'll see, in fact he isn't

[h1]So, now to the actual review[/h1]


The game is currently in Early Access, but stable, constantly patched and fixed and perfectly playable.

The game concept is very innovative and interesting,[b] letting you do things that you wouldn't be able to do in real life but would like to do[/b] (threatening, bribing, manipulating, lying in general, denying, negotiating with the other players ("Bunnies") and so on). 

[b]The goal of the game is to get a certain amount of money before the others do. [/b]There is always one player controlling the giant Robot, controlling weapons that could kill you instantly. But as Overlord (the guy in the robot), you only see what happens in a small area where your spotlight is directed to, and you have to zoom all the way in in order to spot such a small bunny. Just killing the bunnys is not an option in most cases because there would be a respawned bunny knocking on your front door soon. Thus, you will have to effifiencly opress and controll your Bunny slaves to prevent a munity and win the game. If a bunny manages to close to the robot, he will take it over and you will get a little Bunny slave of the mighty Overlord. 

[h1]2 things you should know: [/h1]

1) [b]This game is less about hiding from the Overlord than often assumed.[/b] Of course, you can, but most of the time it's more efficient to earn some money under the eyes of the Overlord.

2) [b]The Overlord is often considered to be "Overpowered" and unbeatable once he is in charge. [/b]However, the Overlord depends on the other bunnies' cooperation, an unmarked bunny roaming around on the map is the worst nightmare of an Overlord. [b]Looking for such a rebellious bunny is like searching drawers for money to spend on Steam games during a blackout in your neighbours house. [/b]

##Hey you, you know what that is like, right?
 
Also, the Overlord often only gets second or third, because the Overlord' property like his beloved Dropshit constantly gets wreckt and he has to rebuy it. And he can't even shoot those rebellious, hiding bunnys anymore because he ran out of rockets and has to convince a bunny to get some for him.

[h1]

[b]Some tactics I invented for little bunnies.[/b]


>As a little slave bunny, you could use the goodwill of the Overlord to win the game. 

>You could bribe other players for whatever reason...

>You could be a snitch and tell the Overlord the position of your fellow hiding slave bunnies to eventually get rewarded by him. 

>Yould hide corpses in the bushes near the feed box and drop them into the box when the overlord is not watching.

>Yould lie to the Overlord and confuse him by saying "there is someone at your door" or use him to get rid of your fellow bunnies ("he just tried to hide your Uranium behind the rock" or "he was stealing my money please do something about it I won't work anymore otherwise") so on.

You could place some of the unremovable alarm boxes at heavily frequented spots, the continous alarms will annoy the Overlord pretty quickly.

>You could distract him while another one secretly sneaks up to the robot. And after this munity, claim the robot yours because you actually were hiding behind a rock close to the robot all the time and left your collar (detectable by the Robot) behind another rock far away and the overlord thought you were hiding there in the back. 

>You could incite a new player to (unintentionally) destroy the Overlords valuable Dropship and drop corpses into the feed box, essentially stealing the Overlords money while he is occupied with his beloved dropship destroyed by a rebellious bunny who claims it was an accident. 
[/h1]

[b]These were only some ways to win I (invented) in my 2-3 hours playtime.[/b] As you can think, the possibilities are [b]near endless already, and the game has just entered early access !![/b]. With friends or some random guys it's incredible fun. The Dev is very friendly and is really dedicated to the game, so make sure you get it!

[h1]Rating: 10/10 I am a good bunny I swear[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198046495652', 'num_games_owned': 3274, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1491401842}
review:
[h1]Review: Obey[/h1]

[i]Footage taken ingame:[/i]

[b]”Kneel down my fellow minions, thou shall obey to my rules and live a happy rabbit life. But those who oppose will be crushed, over and over again! Now offer me some uranium and I shall reward you with money and life. Or at least one of them. Wait! What was that? No..No! Krrchhzzz..
[i]I am in charge now! And what I have to say is: Kneel down my fellow…”[/i][/b]

What was that all about right now? It is about [b]Obey[/b], a multiplayer game, presented in plain but solid graphics, that could revolutionize the whole genre with a unique psychological approach. Do you know “Watership Down”? If not, try to imagine a bunch of small rabbits that start on the same map, trying to get control of a robot. You start as one of those small puppies, running for your life to be the first to enter it. If you succeed, you get rewarded with instant cash and the ability to operate the big guy. That means more cash and the power to control the other rabbits. Or not. If you are second, prepare to get fried by sentries...

[b]Talking about cash.[/b] The main goal of Obey is to be the first who gains 10k Dollars. This can be achieved in multiple ways. You get money every “tick”, meaning a certain period of time, after which your money gets a constant boost. Obtaining the robot triples the amount, rabbits with collars get a bit, “nacked” rabbits get even less. The next option is the “Payout”. That means: The player who is in charge of the robot can place money on the map to gather, manipulate or reward his minions. The last option is the Food or Drop Box. Again, the player controlling the robot can set this box to autopay, cashing your bunnies for delivering special items you need to ensure your reign. These Items get dropped by a Dropship, which also spawns killed rabbits. 

Instead of writing a huge text about them, I will just list the items with a small description:

[u][b]List of items:[/b][/u]
[list]
[*]Uranium - The main-resource and moneymaker. Robot buys it for 100, rabbit dumps it (and earns a small auto-pay), robot gets 300 (win-win)
[*]Rockets - Secondary weapon with much impact. Rabbits get hurt even if they are hiding behind obstacles. 
[*]Fuel - Robot needs it to charge its flamethrower. Very useful to kill nearby rabbits.
[*]Batteries - Sentries surrounding the robot only work if they are activated and that costs batteries. Powerful defense. 
[*]Corpse - Not really a traditional item, but If a bunny dies via Sentry or Flamethrower, it leaves a corpse. Taking and throwing it into the Dropbox, makes the “ruler” lose money. 
[*]Sensors - activates if a bunny is nearby.
[*]Collars - Robots “Main-Spy”. Collars are highlighted with yellow triangles on the map so whoever sits inside the Big Guy can easily see, where the minions are gathering. It can be used to trap the robot as well since it still works even if not worn around a neck, the robot can simply detonate every collar he wishes to. Useful for rabbits: Collars grant more money and protect from enemy sentries. If you made it that far..
[*]Lights - Well, lighting an area so bunnies can be seen although Big Brother isn`t watching with his blaze
[*]Mines - Bunnies can plant them, only robot sees them if they are activate and only robot can deactivate them. At least without dying.
[*]Fences - Or Laser fences - Cheap defense since every bunny gets fried upon touching.
[/list]

[b]Talking about Control.[/b]You might think that being a rabbit outside of the robot is a painful and boring destiny. It is not. Politics and weaving intrigues, manipulating your teammates or even the high ruler himself. How to obey for some minutes? Getting presents in exchange for dumping items and betraying your teammates. Or team up with 2 or 3 others, kill yourself with laser fences and let them dump your corpses into the Dropbox, thus blasting rulers gold away. Losing your collar may look the best opportunity to sneak into the robot but no risk without a price. Wearing no collar means getting less money. And what about the high emperor himself? Should he act violently, showing no mercy and run into the danger of getting attacked from multiple sides? Granting a wish might be a good chance to win a follower. Like it says:[i]”Don`t bite the hand that feeds you.”[/i]
Who needs that robot anyway. My first match was won by a guy that never entered the robot. He always played nice, never taking off his collar. Instead of taking the risk he played after the rules. But not every match is the same and your tactics should be reconsidered every minute to ensure that you are earning the 10k Dollars at first. 

[h1][u]Summary:[/u][/h1]

[b]Update:[/b][i]Obey has been in Early Access for quite some time now - and I still highly recommend it. There are six maps and the map editor, allowing players to build their very own battlefields for free, ensuring nearly infinite possibilities, depending on the community. It should be said that a microphone is expected. There is a chat available but making announcements, threats or plans with teammates does not only work better through the integrated voice chat, it is also way more funny. That said everybody should be aware of the fact that Obey is multiplayer only. Dex managed to implement decent AI that fills the open gaps. Don`t underestimate CPU-Bunnies! They can enter the robot and feel - nothing!!!

I hope lobbies get filled with more people playing since this game may be good with friends but offers a nice new psychological touch when testing your powers of persuasion with strangers. It is not a game for everybody but not only a new approach in a worn-off genre but also a great example for what indie developers can do - so please show your support![/i]

review:
[i]This is my first impression with the EA beta of the game, and I may update it once it's easier to find full matches after Steam release.[/i]

OBEY is very fun and unique multiplayer PvP game about oppression, obedience, subversion, deception, bribery, and all the other fun things you can never have in real life! ;-) It's highly based on communication, and the social interaction makes every round a unique experience. I strongly (!) recommend using a headset/mic to get the full experience.

Each player in the game controls a cute llittle nameless bunny, and to win the round you must earn money faster than your competitors. 
Per default, the earning rate is the same for everyone, except the one bunny controlling the giant, armed-to-the-teeth robot gorilla in the middle of the map, who earns like 10 times!

So will you instantly go for the robot and try to rule them all? To secure your reign, you will have to spend the bigger part of your earnings to buy weapons and resources and then bribe your competitors into feeding those items into your feedbox, and set up defences.

Be a merciless and punishing ruler, killing everyone who disobeys the slightest, and you risk a revolution...
Be a mild and generous sovereign, and you will be used and manipulated into ultimately losing money faster than your clever subordinates earn, only to be pushed from the throne in a second of inattention by simply walking through the robot's front door.

And then there's of course always the subversive ones, constantly trying to manipulate, sneaking around, outright lying or stealing your money by hiding your purchases or dropping dead bunnies in your feedbox....

I had a lot of fun in the few matches I had so far, and I can highly recommend the game to everyone who wants to experience "something different", esp. if you have some close friends to play with. 
Plus the dev Dez is a great guy, constantly present in the chatroom, trying to set up matches and coaching noobs like me or just having a nice talk!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011252982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1614216652}
review:
An original and very tactical game of subversion, deceit and general skullduggery.

Obey brings to the table a fresh approach to the pvp multiplayer experience. The aim of the game is to be the first to achieve a certain monetary goal (usually 10,000 cents) and the means to achieve this goal varies considerably.

At the beginning of each match each player finds themselves in control of a cute little bunny rabbit (a hamster or guinea pig perhaps?). The first player to enter the Robot doorway is the player who gets to control it, thus a race is on. Upon entering the robot the electric sentries will all power up rewarding any late comers with electrocution, there is no second place.

Players earn money in several different ways.

1. Per Tick. Controlling the robot pays the most, wearing an obedience collar pays a little, wearing nothing pays something but not much.

2. Robot Payouts - The player in the robot can drop money wherever he wants in order to reward or manipulate bunnies to obey.

3. Drop Box - The robot can set the Drop Box to autopay on deposit (25,50,75 or 100) in order to encourage the bunnies to deposit items.

Items
'''''''''''"
Uranium - Costs 100 - Pays the Robot 300 when deposited (ie. Robot can buy it for 100, bunny can then deposit it for autopay of 100, robot and player therefore make 100 profit each). 

Batteries - Provides a single charge to the sentry defences whereby the robot, upon activating said charge, will cause all nearby bunnies without a collar to be electrocuted. Bunnies can protect themselves by hiding behind wreckage they drop between themselves and the defence pylon.

Fuel - Ammunition for the the robots flamethrower which is the only weapon which can directly shoot the robot doorway.

Rockets - Ammunition for the robots multiple rocket launcher. The robot can kill bunnies hiding behind obstacles with this.

Mines - Once deployed only the robot can see where they are.

Laser Fence - A deployable fence which will instantly fry any bunny walking into it.

Pointer - Allows bunnies to temporarily mark a location on the map. These are usually used by bunnies who take upon the role of an informant on behalf of the robot against their fellow bunnies.

Sensors - Indicates when a bunny is nearby.

Lights - Keeps an area lit as the robot can generally only see where the searchlight is aimed.

Collars - Obedience collars allow the player in the robot to easily see the location of the bunny wearing it. The robot can also destroy the collar thus killing the bunny whom is wearing it. Collars grant a bunny immunity to the robots sentry defences. They also generate an increased income for the wearer.

Corpses - These are left behind when a bunny is electrocuted or burned and when deposited in the Drop Box they cause the player controlling the robot to lose money.


Players have to decide, moment by moment, how they will play the game. Should they obey the robot and make some money doing so, yet by doing so they empower the player controlling the robot? Should they spend their time trying to subvert the robot whereby they could reap huge gains yet in the meantime not be making much money? Should they inform on the other bunnies or should they perhaps try and corpse the robot? Should they cast dispersion on the other players with subtle comments? Should they tactfully try and create a certain atmosphere amongst the other players? Should they band together with the other bunnies against the player in the lead? Should they lure other players via baiting them to do certain things? The choices are ongoing and dynamic and are only really limited to our cognitive ability.

The game has fully integrated voice chat and therefore a microphone is essential to get the most out of the experience. Players reliant on keyboard only to communicate will be at a significant disadvantage in regards to their ability to influence the other players.


After having played numerous games I emphatically give this title a thumbs up and highly recommend people pick themselves up a copy. This game will definitely bring out the worst in you and at the same time bring a smile to your face as you see the worst brought out in others.

Town of Salem was good, but this is much better. :)



Brave New World + Nineteen Eighty-Four + Propaganda (Bernays) + Pavlov + Sun Tzu + Computer Code = Obey.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032828514', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1443273437}
review:
OBEY is a unique and hectic multiplayer game where the mechanics are intentionally designed to allow any player to make up the rules, and any player may also disOBEY those rules.

The giant Robot isn't the only player in power: the bunnies can lie, haggle, and masquerade to get what they want. Anything is fair game in OBEY, taking what's not yours, pretending you're working for the Robot and then dumping all his supplies into a creek when he turns away, and even demanding payment for telling the Robot when other bunnies are misbehaving.

Every game is vastly different, as every player brings their own strategies to the table. This is a psychological war, and a struggle to maintain control in a world were everyone wants to stab you in the back.

The sole developer, Danial Dez, has been [b]exceptionally[/b] involved in the community of his game, appearing whenever questions are asked, is very attentive to community suggestions, and even very frequently goes and rounds up players when there's a game underway. 10/10
